revision.comment: /* Circumstances of her death */ removed diatribe OR [[WP:HIJACKING]]
revision.text:
{{pp-move-indef}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = Nedâ Âghâ-Soltân |image = Neda Agha-Soltan.jpg |image_size = 150px |caption = Photo by Caspian Makan |birth_name = |birth_date = 23 January 1983 |birth_place = [[Tehran]], Iran |death_date = 15 June 2009 (aged 26) |death_place = West of Kârgar Avenue at the intersection between Khowsravi and Sâlehi Streets,
[[Tehrān]], Iran
{{Coord|35|43|8.57|N|51|23|30.60|E|display=inline|name=Location of the death of Neda Agha-Soltan|type:event}} |death_cause = Shot |resting_place = [[Behesht-e Zahrā cemetery]], southern [[Tehran]] |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = Meshkini Street, [[Tehranpars|Tehrānpars]] neighborhood, [[Tehran|Tehrān]][http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,529086,00.html Neda Soltan's Family Reportedly Forced Out of Home by Iranian Authorities]. [[Fox News Channel|Fox News]]. 25 June 2009. |nationality = Iranian |alma_mater = [[Islamic Azad University|Islamic Āzād University]] (second semester of Theology)http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/23/iran.neda.profile/index.html[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/election-outrage-that-turned-neda-into-a-political-protester-1715995.html Election outrage that turned Neda into a political protester]; Guy Adams, [[The Independent]], 24 June 2009 |employer = Family's [[travel agency]] |known_for = Death during the [[2009 Iranian election protests]] |party = Known as generally apolitical |footnotes = |relations = }} Footage of the '''death of Neda Agha-Soltan''' ({{lang-fa|ندا آقاسلطان}} – ''Nedâ Âghâ-Soltân''; 23 January 1983 – 20 June 2009) drew worldwide attention after she was shot dead during the [[2009 Iranian election protests]]. Agha-Soltan, a student of philosophy, was participating in the protests, accompanied by her music teacher, and was walking back to her car when she was fatally shot in the chest. The murderer of Neda is disputed. According to Western media outlets such as [[CNN]], the [[BBC]] and [[Fox News]], she was shot by the [[Basij]], a paramilitary organization. Her death was captured on video by bystanders and broadcast over the Internet, and the video became a rallying point for the opposition. Agha-Soltan's death became iconic in the struggle of Iranian protesters against the disputed election of President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]].[http://100photos.time.com/photos/death-of-neda The Death of Neda | 100 Photographs | The Most Influential Images of All Time] ==Etymology== ''Nedā'' (ندا) is a word used in [[Persian language#Classic Persian|Classic Persian]] and modern [[Persian language|Persian]]'''ندا''' has been borrowed from the same [[Classical Arabic]] word (a verb in Arabic) meaning "get together", "meet with", then "gather", "come together", "call together", "rally". It is a synonym of ''اجتمع''. A lot more meanings are given in dictionaries like ''Wörterbuch der Klassischen Arabischen Sprache (Dictionary of Classical Arabic)'', by Manfred Ullmann, Edward William Lane, the Arabic and Persian ''Moungued dictionaries -قواميس المنجد'' and many more. to mean "voice", "calling" (sometimes understood as a "divine message", but this is not the etymological sense of ''ندا''), and she has been referred to as the "voice of Iran".{{cite news |issn=0040-781X |last=Chua-eoan |first=Howard |title=What the World Didn't See in Tehran |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=21 June 2009 |date=21 June 2009 |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1906040,00.html}}{{cite news |title=Iran TV says 10 died in protests |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=21 June 2009 |date=21 June 2009 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8111352.stm |quote=Witness accounts on Saturday suggested police used live rounds, batons, tear gas, and water cannon to break up demonstrations that went on late into the night. Among unconfirmed material posted on the internet after Saturday's protests, a brief graphic video clip appearing to show a teenage girl dying from a wound, has fueled anti-government feelings. The girl, who has been called Nedā, had been protesting with her father in Tehran when she was shot.}}{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/us_world/2009/06/21/2009-06-21_neda_young_girl_killed_in_iraq.html |title=Neda, young girl killed in Iran, becoming symbol of rebellion |work=[[New York Daily News]] |last=Kennedy |first=Helen |date=22 June 2009 |accessdate=24 June 2009}}{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==Biography== Agha-Soltan was the middle child of a middle-class family of three children, whose family resided in a fourth floor flat on Meshkini Street in the [[Tehranpars]] district of Tehran.Correspondent in Tehran (24 June 2009). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jun/24/neda-soltan-iran-family-forced-out Neda Soltan's family 'forced out of home' by Iranian authorities]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Her father is a civil servant and her mother is a homemaker. She was graduating from [[Islamic Azad University]], where she had studied Islamic theology as well as secular philosophies, but she withdrew after two semesters of study for two reasons, one being a disagreement with her husband Amir and his family, and the other being the atmosphere and the pressure of the authorities towards her appearance and dress in the university.Connett, David (28 June 2009).[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/iran-online-around-the-world-in-60-minutes-1722467.html Iran online: Around the world in 60 minutes]. ''[[The Independent]]''. She was divorced, and according to her mother, had difficulty in finding work because of how employers perceived her.Wayne Drash and Octavia Nasr (5 November 2009). [http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/11/05/neda.mom.speaks/index.html Neda's mother: She was 'like an angel']. ''[[CNN]]''. Agha-Soltan was an aspiring [[underground music|underground musician]], who was studying her craft through private voice and music lessons.May, Rachel (22 August 2003).[http://www.csmonitor.com/2003/0822/p08s02-wome.html In Iran, no men allowed at women's music fest]. ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]''. She had studied the violin and had an as-yet-undelivered piano on order at the time of her death.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/23/iran.neda.profile/index.html |work=CNN |title=Who was Neda? Slain woman an unlikely martyr |accessdate=1 May 2010 |date=24 June 2009}} She worked for her family's travel agency.Farber, Daniel (23 June 2009) It was in [[Turkey]], more than two months prior to her death, that she met her fiancé, 37-year-old Caspian Makan, who worked as a photojournalist and filmmaker in [[Tehran]], and after that she changed her mind about becoming a tour guide and decided to start photography with him. Agha-Soltan enjoyed travelling. She had studied [[Turkish language|Turkish]], hoping it would aid her as a guide for Iranians on foreign tours in Turkey.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jun/22/neda-soltani-death-iran |title=How Neda Agha-Soltan became the face of Iran's struggle |last=Tait |first=Robert |author2=Weaver, Matthew |date=22 June 2009 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=23 June 2009 |location=London}} Those who knew her maintain that Agha-Soltan had not previously been very political – she had not supported any particular candidate in the 2009 Iran elections{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/06/13/iran-demonstrations-viole_n_215189.html |title=Live-blogging the uprising |work=The Huffington Post |date=23 June 2009 |accessdate=24 June 2009 |last=Pitney |first=Nico}} – but that anger over the election results prompted her to join the protest. Her [[voice teacher|voice]] and [[music teacher]], Hamid Panahi, who was accompanying Agha-Soltan during the protest and can be seen on the video trying to comfort the dying woman, told the media: "She couldn't stand the injustice of it." Panahi went on to state: "All she wanted was the proper vote of the people to be counted." ===Confusion regarding identity=== Her name is often miscited as "Neda Soltani". [[Neda Soltani]] is a different woman, whose Facebook profile photo was mistakenly published in many articles about the incident. She tried in vain to remove her photo from the internet. Claims from both sides have been made, including claims from the Iranian government that she was the same person as Agha-Soltan and had faked her own death; and others who claimed that she was herself an agent of the Iranian government impersonating Agha-Soltan to sully her memory. Within two weeks, she had fled from Iran and was granted [[asylum in Germany]] in 2010.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/oct/14/iran-neda-soltani-id-mix-up|title=Iranian fugitive: identity mix-up with shot Neda wrecked my life|publisher=The Guardian|date=14 October 2012|author=Tracy McVeigh|accessdate=2012-11-14}}{{de icon}} [[David Schraven]], [http://sz-magazin.sueddeutsche.de/texte/anzeigen/32571 ''Das zweite Leben der Neda Soltani''], Süddeutsche Zeitung Magazin, Heft 05/2010. Consulted on February 6, 2010.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iPD-wzCdHuXjid8AqB2gs2iqtn7Q ''Iranian mistaken for 'Neda' seeks German asylum''], AFP. Consulted on February 6, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.anorak.co.uk/214504/media/neda-soltani-is-alive.html|title=How The Media Betrayed Neda Soltani|publisher=Anorak.co.uk|accessdate=2012-11-14}} ==Circumstances of her death== On 20 June 2009, at around 6:30 p.m., Neda Agha-Soltan was sitting in her [[Peugeot 206]] in traffic on [[Kargar Avenue]] in [[Tehran]].{{cite news |title='Neda' becomes rallying cry for Iranian protests |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=22 June 2009 |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/21/iran.woman.twitter/ |accessdate=24 June 2009}}[http://www.foxnews.com/story/2009/06/22/neda-soltan-young-woman-hailed-as-martyr-in-iran-becomes-face-protests/]{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8113552.stm |title=BBC NEWS — Middle East — Death video woman 'targeted by militia' |publisher=}} She was accompanied by her music teacher, Hamid Panahi.{{cite news |last=Daragahi |first=Borzou |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-neda23-2009jun23,0,366975,full.story |title=Family, friends mourn 'Neda,' Iranian woman who died on video |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=23 June 2009 |accessdate=23 June 2009}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/23/world/middleeast/23neda.html |title=In a death seen around the world, a symbol of Iranian protests |last=Fathi |first=Nazila |date=22 June 2009 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=24 June 2009}} They were on their way to participate in the protests against the results of the [[2009 Iranian presidential election]].{{cite news |title=Neda Agha Soltan's story touches everyone except Iran's rulers |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6565497.ece |work=The Times |year=2009 |accessdate=2009 |location=London |first=Martin |last=Fletcher}}{{cite news |title=Neda: Latest iconic image to inspire |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/24/neda.iconic.images/ |last=Ravitz |first=Jessica |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=24 June 2009 |accessdate=24 June 2009}} The car's air conditioner was not working well, so she stopped her car some distance from the main protests and got out on foot to escape the heat. She was standing and observing the sporadic protests in the area when she was shot in the chest.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8113552.stm |title=Death video woman 'targeted by militia' |date=22 June 2009 |accessdate=24 June 2009 |publisher=[[BBC News]]}}{{Cite news |title=Iran: Violent Crackdown on Protesters Widens |date=24 June 2009 |agency=HumanRightsWatch |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2009/06/23/iran-violent-crackdown-protesters-widens |accessdate=7 November 2013}} As captured on amateur video, she collapsed to the ground and was attended to by a doctor, her music teacher, and others from the crowd. Someone in the crowd around her shouted, "She has been shot! Someone, come and take her!"{{cite news |title=Who was Neda? Slain woman an unlikely martyr |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/23/iran.neda.profile/index.html |date=24 June 2009 |accessdate=28 June 2009 |work=CNN}} The videos were accompanied by a message from a doctor, later identified as [[Arash Hejazi]], who said he had been present during the incident (but fled Iran out of fear of government reprisals):{{cite news |title=Doctor flees Iran over "Neda" killing |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE55P1IZ20090626 |publisher=Reuters |date=26 June 2009 |accessdate=26 June 2009}} {{blockquote|At 19:05, on 20 June Place: Kargar Ave., at the corner crossing Khowsravi St. and Salehi St. A young woman who was standing aside with her father [sic, later identified as her music teacher] watching the protests was shot by a Basij member hiding on the rooftop of a civilian house. He had clear shot at the girl and could not miss her. However, he aimed straight at her heart. I am a doctor, so I rushed to try to save her. But the impact of the gunshot was so fierce that the bullet had blasted inside the victim's chest, and she died in less than two minutes. The protests were going on about one kilometre away in the main street and some of the protesting crowd were running from tear gas used among them, towards Salehi St. The film is shot by my friend who was standing beside me.{{cite news |url=http://blogs.usatoday.com/ondeadline/2009/06/in-.html |title=In Iran, one woman – Neda – becomes a symbol |date=21 June 2009 |accessdate=24 June 2009 |publisher=[[USA Today]] |last=DeRoy |first=Glenna}}}} Her last words were, "I'm burning, I'm burning!" according to Panahi. She died en route to Tehran's Shariati hospital.{{cite news |title=Neda Agha Soltan |work=[[The Times]] |date=23 June 2009 |accessdate=24 June 2009 |first=Jenny |last=Booth |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6562649.ece |location=London}} However, the civilian physician who tended to Neda in the video stated that Neda died on the scene.{{youtube|id=C4-iLG6FwRc22|title=Neda: An Iranian Martyr [BBC Documentary]}}{{youtube|id=mYN53BOeijY|title=HBO The True Story of Neda Agha-Soltan زندگي ندا آقا سلطان ايران}} Hejazi, standing one metre away from her when she was shot, tried to stanch her wound with his hands. Hejazi said nearby members of the crowd pulled a man from his motorcycle while shouting: "We got him, we got him," disarmed him, obtained his identity card and identified him as a member of the [[Basij]] government militia. The militiaman was shouting, "I didn't want to kill her." The protesters let him go, but they kept the alleged killer's identity card and took many photographs of him.{{refn|According to an eyewitness, Dr. Ārash Hejāzi.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8119713.stm News.bbc.co.uk]|name=BBC Hejazi}} A recent documentary on the shooting contained a previously unseen clip of demonstrators capturing the militiaman seconds after the shooting.{{cite web |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6917831.ece |title=Login |publisher=}} Iranian state TV alleged that Neda Agha-Soltani was carrying blood in a concealed vessel within her mouth, a common practice of the [[People's Mujahedin of Iran|MKO]], which she then broke to resemble internal bleeding.Golnaz Esfandiari, [https://www.rferl.org/a/Iran_State_TV_Suggests_Iconic_Protest_Death_Faked/1923414.html "Iran State TV Suggests Neda's Iconic Death Was 'Faked'"] – [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]], 7 January 2010 ===Videos=== {{See also|Role of the Internet during 2009 Iranian election protests}} [[File:Neda non graphic.jpg|thumb|A frame from the video of Agha-Soltan's death by gunfire]] The videos spread across the internet [[Viral video|virally]], quickly gaining the attention of international media and viewers.Langendonck, Gert Van (23 June 2009). [http://www.nrc.nl/international/article2280315.ece/Iconic_Iran_video_was_posted_in_the_Netherlands Iconic Iran video was posted in the Netherlands]. ''[[NRC Handelsblad]]''. Discussions about the incident on Twitter, using a [[hashtag]] of #neda, became one of the "'trending topics'" by the end of the day on 20 June 2009. The incident was not originally reported by the state-controlled Iranian media, but was instead first reported on by international media. The video was shown on [[CNN]] and other news networks.{{cite web |title=Youtube – Neda's Death Becomes Iranian Symbol: News Current |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZmrB2FOLqiE |accessdate=7 December 2010}} There are three videos depicting her death. One shows her collapsing to the ground, apparently still conscious.{{cite web |title=Young girl being killed by plain-clothes |accessdate=22 June 2009 |url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=0db_1245519048 |publisher=LiveLeak}} The second shows her only after she appears to lose consciousness and begins to bleed heavily.{{cite web |title=Girl shot by police – Second Angle |url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=fe5_1245534854 |accessdate=22 June 2009 |publisher=LiveLeak}} The third video shows her just as she begins to bleed profusely.{{cite web |title=Iran – New Footage of Neda's Death (Graphic) – Third Angle |url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=b1d_1276271267 |accessdate=17 June 2010 |publisher=LiveLeak}} In the first video, the cameraman approaches a group of people huddled together in front of a parked car at the side of the street. As he moves closer, she can be seen collapsing to the pavement with a large bloodstain at her feet. Two men, Hamid Panahi and Arash Hejazi, are seen trying to revive her. As seconds pass, her eyes roll to one side and she appears to lose consciousness. Blood begins to pour from her nose and mouth, and screams are heard. The man next to her can apparently be heard speaking in the first video, saying her name:
Neda, don't be afraid. Neda, don't be afraid. [obscured by others yelling] Neda, stay with me. Neda stay with me!
In the second video, the cameraman approaches her and the two men; the camera passes over them and centers on her face; her stare is blank and she is bleeding profusely from her nose and mouth. Loud screaming can be heard. Agha-Soltan's death was "probably the most widely witnessed death in human history," according to ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine.{{cite news |title=Neda Agha Soltan |url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1945379_1944701_1944705,00.html |last=Mahr |first=Krista |publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=8 December 2009 |accessdate=1 May 2010}} The videos were awarded the [[George Polk Award]] for Videography in 2009.{{cite news |title=Anonymous video of Neda Aghan-Soltan's death wins Polk award |last=Bunz |first=Mercedes |publisher=[[The Guardian]]: PDA The Digital Content Blog |date=16 February 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/pda/2010/feb/16/george-polk-awards/ |accessdate=13 June 2010 |location=London}} ==Alleged killer== The man accused by opposition sources of killing Neda Agha-Soltan was identified as [[Abbas Kargar Javid]], a Basij government militiaman, after photographs of the Basiji's ID cards appeared on the internet, according to ''[[The Times]]''.{{cite news |title=The face of Abbas Kargar Javid – man accused of killing Neda Soltan |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6802669.ece |accessdate=21 May 2011 |newspaper=The Times |date=20 August 2009 |author=Martin Fletcher |location=London}} Opposition critics and pro-government sources allege that Western intelligence agencies carried out the shooting.Eric Verlo, [http://notmytribe.com/2009/who-killed-neda-soltani-88127.html "Who Killed Neda Agha-Soltan?"] – Not My Tribe, 22 June 2009Robert Mackey, [https://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/07/iranian-tv-sees-conspiracy-in-neda-video/ "Iranian TV Sees Conspiracy in Neda Video"] – [[The New York Times]], 7 January 2010Golnaz Esfandiari, [https://www.rferl.org/a/Iran_State_TV_Suggests_Iconic_Protest_Death_Faked/1923414.html "Iran State TV Suggests Neda's Iconic Death Was 'Faked'"] – [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]], 7 January 2010 ==Aftermath== [[File:Grave of Neda.jpg|thumb|left|185px|Grave site immediately following burial]] After being pronounced dead at Shari'ati hospital, Agha-Soltan was buried at the [[Behesht-e Zahra]] cemetery in southern Tehran; she was denied a proper funeral by government authorities.{{cite news|last=Weissenstein |first=Michael |last2=Johnson |first2=Anna |title=Amateur video turns woman into icon of Iran unrest |agency=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=22 June 2009 |date=22 June 2009 |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090622/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election_icon |publisher=[[Yahoo News]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090625133045/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090622/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election_icon |archivedate=25 June 2009 }} The authorities had allegedly set aside empty graves for those killed during the protests. Her family agreed to the removal of her organs for [[organ transplant|transplanting]] to medical patients. The Iranian government issued a ban on collective prayers in mosques for Agha-Soltan in the aftermath of the incident.{{cite news |last=McElroy |first=Damien |title=Iran bans prayers for 'Angel of Freedom' Neda Agha-Soltan |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=24 June 2009 |date=22 June 2009 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/5603057/Iran-bans-prayers-for-Angel-of-Freedom-Neda-Agha-Soltan.html |location=London}} Opposition figure Soona Samsami, the executive director of the Women's Freedom Forum, who was relaying information about the protests inside Iran to international media outlets, told the foreign press that Agha-Soltan's immediate family were threatened by authorities if they permitted a gathering to mourn her.{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,528441,00.html |title=Iran's 'angel of freedom' Neda Soltan vowed to protest against injustice |publisher=[[Fox News]] |date=23 June 2009 |accessdate=24 June 2009}} Samsami stated, "They were threatened that if people wanted to gather there the family would be charged and punished." Caspian Makan (Agha-Soltan's fiancé) told the BBC: "Neda had said that even if she lost her life and got a bullet in her heart, she would carry on."{{cite news |last=Sheikholeslami |first=Ali |author2=Alexander, Caroline |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aHvSY8wNfM_M |title=Neda's killing propels Iran's women to more opposition protests |date=23 June 2009 |accessdate=23 June 2009}} Pro-government activists have cited this as contradictory to the claim of not being involved in the protests and simply being in the area due to the breakdown of the air conditioning in her car. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' and other news sources speculated that because of the widespread attention given to Āghā-Soltān's story by [[social media]] networks and mainstream news organizations, she is already being hailed as a [[martyr]]. There was also speculation that the [[Shia Islam|Shi'ite]] cycle of [[mourning]] on the third (23 June), seventh (27 June), and 40th (30 July) day after a person's death may give the protests sustained momentum, in similar fashion to the [[Iranian Revolution]], where each commemoration of a demonstrator's death sparked renewed protests, resulting in more deaths, feeding a cycle that eventually resulted in the overthrowing of [[Pahlavi dynasty|Iran's monarchy]].{{cite news |last=Wright |first=Robin |title=In Iran, one woman's death may have many consequences |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=23 June 2009 |date=21 June 2009 |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1906049,00.html}} On 22 June, Iranian presidential candidates [[Mehdi Karroubi]] and [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]], who were contesting the validity of the election of [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]], called upon Iranian citizens to commemorate Āghā-Soltān. Karroubi announced his appeal on Facebook, asking demonstrators to gather in the center of the Iranian capital at 4:00 pm local time. The chief of the Tehran Police announced that his department had no involvement in the fatal incident.Hendelman-Baavur, Liora (25 June 2009). [http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1245184921949&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Analysis: Hell hath no fury]. ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]''. Later that day, riot police armed with [[live ammunition]] and tear gas dispersed a crowd of between 200 and 1,000 protesters who had gathered in Tehran's Haft-e Tir Square. The protests followed online calls for tribute to Āghā-Soltān and others killed during the demonstrations.{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090623/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election |title=Iran's top electoral body rules out vote annulment people in Tehran's Haft-e Tir square after on-line calls for protesters to pay tribute to Neda |date=23 June 2009 |accessdate=23 June 2009 |last=Kole |first=William J. |agency=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=[[Yahoo News]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626110615/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090623/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election |archivedate=26 June 2009 }} [[Grand Ayatollah Hossein-Ali Montazeri]], a senior Iranian cleric and vocal critic of [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]], called for three days of public mourning for the death of Nedā. Cāspian Mākān, following Nedā's death, escaped to Canada. He visited [[Israel]] in March 2010 as a guest of Israel's [[Channel 2 (Israel)|Channel 2]] and stated "I have come here out of the brotherhood of nations."{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Article.aspx?id=171380 |title=Neda's fiance: Iran will be free |work=The Jerusalem Post — JPost.com}} ===Funeral=== About 70 mourners gathered outside Niloufar mosque in [[Abbas Abad (Tehran)|Abbas Abad]], where the Āghā-Soltān family attended services. A leaflet posted on the mosque's door read, "There is no commemoration here for Nedā Āghā-Soltān." Many in the crowd wore black. Some recited poems. After about ten minutes, paramilitary forces arrived on motorcycles and dispersed the attendees.[http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2009/06/the-world-mourns-neda.html Political Punch]; ABC News, 23 June 2009 On 23 June, it was reported that, to prevent Āghā-Soltān's family's home from becoming a place of pilgrimage, government authorities told the family to remove the black mourning banners from outside the home.{{cite news |title=Iranian authorities scramble to negate Neda Soltan 'martyrdom' |work=[[The Times]] |date=23 June 2009 |accessdate=24 June 2009 |first=Jenny |last=Booth |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6561253.ece |location=London}} On 24 June, ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported the results of interviews of neighbours who said Āghā-Soltān's family had been forced to vacate their apartment some days after her death.{{cite news |title=Neda Soltan's family 'forced out of home' by Iranian authorities |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=24 June 2009 |accessdate=24 June 2009 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jun/24/neda-soltan-iran-family-forced-out |location=London}} [[Reuters]] reported that supporters of presidential candidate [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]] stated they would release thousands of balloons on 26 June 2009 with the message "Nedā you will always remain in our hearts" imprinted on them.[https://www.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUSTRE55F54520090625?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews Reuters: ''Ahmadinejad compares Obama to Bush''. 24 June 2009] Retrieved 24 June 2009 On 31 July 2009, the 40th day from the killings of such youth as Nedā Āghā-Soltān, [[Sohrab Aarabi|Sohrāb Ā'arābi]] and Āshkān Sohrābi was held in Tehran where thousands of Iranians mourned for the loss of the victims.{{cite news |title=Iran witnesses: Neda memorial |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8176961.stm |date=31 July 2009 |accessdate=7 December 2010 |work=[[BBC]]}} Reports also came of gatherings in the thousands in cities of [[Rasht]], [[Shiraz|Shirāz]] and Mashad.{{cite news |title=Footage emerges from demonstrations across the country |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/07/iran-footage-emerges-from-demonstrations-across-the-country.html |date=31 July 2009 |accessdate=7 December 2010 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |last=Smith |first=Amber |location=Los Angeles}} ====Grave desecration==== [[File:Graveyard.jpg|thumb|Neda Agha-Soltan's gravesite in Beheshte-Zahra, 2011]] On 16 November 2009, supporters of the Iranian regime desecrated her grave and removed her gravestone. Later, on 31 December 2009, supporters of the Iranian government defaced the portrait on her grave by shooting at it multiple times.{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6979914.ece |work=The Times |location=London |title=Neda Soltans grave defaced as Iran issues new internet restrictions |first=Martin |last=Fletcher |date=8 January 2010 |accessdate=1 May 2010}} ===CIA conspiracy theory=== Iran's ambassador to [[Mexico]], Mohammad Hassan Ghadiri, suggested in an interview on 25 June 2009 that the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] could have been involved in Āghā-Soltān's death. Ambassador Ghadiri questioned how the shooting was video taped so effectively, asserting that the incident occurred away from other demonstrations. He also stated that using a woman would be more effective in accomplishing the goals the CIA is purported to desire.Malcolm, Andrew (25 June 2009). [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2009/06/neda-cia-cnn-killing.html Iran ambassador suggests CIA could have killed Neda Agha-Soltan]. Los Angeles Times. Ambassador Ghadiri said "the bullet that was found in her head was not a bullet that you could find in Iran." (he thought she was shot in head.) The account of Doctor Hejazi was that Āghā-Soltān was shot in the chest from the front, as there was no exit wound, and the video evidence showing a wound to the chest.{{Cite news |title=Iran doctor tells of Neda's death |work=BBC |accessdate=2 July 2009 |date=25 June 2009 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8119713.stm}} Hejāzi was the man seen in the video placing his hands on Āghā-Soltān's chest to staunch her bleeding (as described above under section [[#Circumstances of death|Circumstances of death]]). Wolf Blitzer was incredulous that Ghadiri would so boldly offer a [[conspiracy theory]] or obvious [[disinformation]] as an explanation: {{blockquote|1= BLITZER: ..You're a distinguished diplomat representing Iran. This is a very serious accusation that you're making, that the CIA was responsible for killing this beautiful, young woman. GHADIRI (through interpreter): I'm not saying that the CIA had done this. There are different groups. Could be intelligence services, could be CIA, could be the terrorists. However, these are the people who do these things. You could ask Mr. Andreotti, who was an Italian diplomat, whether [[Operation Gladio|Gladiators]] were a secret group related to CIA or not... }} ===Claim of protester shooting=== During his Friday sermon on June 26, the Supreme Leader's appointed speaker, Ayatollah Ahmad Khatami, said "evidence shows that [protesters] have done it themselves and have raised propaganda against the system."{{Cite news |last=Erdbrink |first=Thomas |author2=William Branigin |title=Iranian cleric says protesters wage war against God |work=The Boston Globe |accessdate=2 July 2009 |date=27 June 2009 |url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/middleeast/articles/2009/06/27/iranian_cleric_says_protesters_wage_war_against_god/}} Eyewitnesses at the scene of the shooting said Āghā-Soltān was shot by a member of the pro-government [[Basij]] militia.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8113552.stm Death video woman 'targeted by militia']. [[BBC News]]. 22 June 2009.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8119713.stm Iran doctor tells of Neda's death]. [[BBC News]]. 25 June 2009.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/06/23/2606131.htm Basij militia 'targeting women']. [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]. 23 June 2009. Some of the eyewitnesses say she was shot from the ground, some say from the rooftop. ===Arrest warrant for witness=== Iran's police chief, brigadier general Āhmadi-Moghaddam told the press on 30 June 2009 that the Iranian police and [[Ministry of Intelligence and National Security of Iran|Ministry of Intelligence]] filed an arrest warrant for [[Interpol]] to arrest Ārash Hejāzi, an eyewitness of Nedā's death, for poisoning the international atmosphere against the Iranian government and telling misinformation about Nedā's death by giving his account of the incident to foreign news media.{{Cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/2009/07/090701_ka_ir88_hejazi_ahmadimoghadam.shtml|script-title=fa:فرمانده نیروی انتظامی: شاهد مرگ ندا تحت تعقیب وزارت اطلاعات و پلیس بین الملل است |language=Persian |publisher=[[BBC Persian]]}} ==Iranian government's claims of video fabrication== [[Ezzatollah Zarghami]], the head of [[Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting]], told the press on 4 July 2009 that the videos of Nedā's death were all made by [[BBC]] and [[CNN]].{{Cite news |url=http://tabannews.net/totla.php?id=4642|script-title=fa:ضرغامی: در انتخابات ونزوئلا هم یک نفر مثل "ندا" را کشتند! |language=Persian |publisher=Taban News}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.iranuk88.com/article.php?id=39219|script-title=fa:ادعاي عجيب ضرغامي: تصوير قتل ندا آقاسلطان ساختگي است |language=Persian |publisher=Iranian}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.ayandenews.com/fa/pages/?cid=9643|script-title=fa:ضرغامی:در ونزوئلا هم ندا کشتند تا بگویند رای چاوز هم ساختگی است |language=Persian |publisher=Ayande News}} In December 2009, Iranian state television aired a report about Āghā-Soltān's death, portraying it as a western plot. In the programme, it was argued that Āghā-Soltān simulated her death with accomplices, and that she was killed afterwards, having no knowledge of her partners' intentions.{{youtube|id=Shp7HE2YA_c|title=Nedas Death – The other Side of the Coin,''Press TV''}} ===Government pressure for confession=== According to ''The Times'', quoted from Mākān and Āghā-Soltān's parents, officials tried to get them to confess that it was opposition protestors that had killed Nedā, and not government militiamen. They were given incentives such as declaring Nedā to be a martyr and giving the family a pension if they complied. Makan and Nedā's family refused the offer. Panāhi was later forced by the government to change his story. The new version of events were retold by Panāhi on state television.[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/tehranbureau/deathintehran/view/ A Death in Tehran], at PBS ===Accusation of security forces=== In December 2009, her family accused the security forces of killing her, although even most western press accounts so far have stopped short of calling it a targeted political assassination. This was the strongest statement the family of Nedā Āghā-Soltān made since her death. This accusation followed the spread of an Iranian government-proposed theory blaming a "conspiracy of western governments" for the killing. Her father told the [[BBC]]'s Persian service by telephone from Iran: "I openly declare that no one, apart from the government, killed Nedā. Her killer can only be from the government."{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8396052.stm |title=BBC News — Neda Agha Soltan's family accuse Iran of her killing |publisher=}} ==Scholarship== {{Main|Neda Agha-Soltan Graduate Scholarship}} The Neda Agha-Soltan Graduate Scholarship is a scholarship for post-graduate philosophy students at [[The Queen's College, Oxford]], with preference given to students of Iranian citizenship or heritage. The college received offers from two anonymous donors to establish a scholarship, followed by many individual donations from members of the public, former students of Queen's and others to reach the £70,000 needed to establish the scholarship on a permanent basis.{{Cite web |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6935464.ece |title=Diplomats uneasy at Neda Soltan being honoured by Queen's College, Oxford |last=Kerbaj |first=Richard |work=The Times |date=28 November 2009 |accessdate=1 February 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.queens.ox.ac.uk/news/endowment-of-neda-agha-soltan-scholarship |title=Endowment of Neda Agha-Soltan Scholarship |publisher=The Queen's College, Oxford |year=2014 |accessdate=9 June 2014}} The first recipient of the scholarship was Arianne Shahvis, a philosophy student of Iranian descent, who described the award as "a great honour".{{Cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100109143044/http://www.queens.ox.ac.uk/news/index.php |archivedate=9 January 2010 |url=http://www.queens.ox.ac.uk/news/index.php |title=News: Neda Agha-Soltan Graduate Scholarship |publisher=The Queen's College, Oxford |accessdate=1 February 2010}} In November 2009, Iran's embassy in London sent a letter of protest to the college about the scholarship.{{Cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6911629.ece |title=Oxford's tribute to student Neda Soltan denounced by Iran |work=The Times |date=11 November 2009 |author=Fletcher, Martin |author2=Hurst, Greg |accessdate=1 February 2010}} ==See also== {{Portal|Iran|Death}} * [[Chain murders of Iran]] – a series of murders of dissident voices made to appear as accidents and suicides * [[Sohrab Aarabi]] * [[Taraneh Mousavi]] * [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed]] * [[Death of Hamza Ali Al-Khateeb]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.openculture.com/2010/06/for_neda_a_new_hbo_documentary.html For Neda (2010)]; HBO Documentary Films - About Neda Agha-Soltan and her life story * {{youtube|id=YN-VIxONSbA|title=Documentary investigating the death of Neda Agha-Soltan, with pictures and witness accounts}} * [http://www.liu.edu/Brooklyn/About/News/Newsletters/~/media/Files/Brooklyn/About/NewsEvents/BrooklynBeat/BBspring2010.ashx Video of her death wins prestigious 2009 George Polk Award for Videography] * [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/nov/15/iran-neda-caspian-makan-interview Caspian Makan: 'I cannot believe it yet. I still think I will see Neda again']; The Guardian, 15 November 2009 * [http://www.time.com/time/photogallery/0,29307,1906549,00.html Photos: Who Was Neda Agha-Soltan?] – a photo essay by ''TIME'' * [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/5603057/Iran-bans-prayers-for-Angel-of-Freedom-Neda-Agha-Soltan.html Iran Bans Prayers for 'Angel of Freedom' Neda Agha Soltan]; Damien McElroy, The Telegraph, 22 June 2009 * [http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-neda23-2009jun23,0,366975,full.story Family, Friends Mourn 'Neda']; Borzou Daragahi, Los Angeles Times, 23 June 2009 * [http://en.qantara.de/webcom/show_article.php/_c-310/_nr-762/i.html Neda, an Opera by Nader Mashayekhi: Pathos without Kitsch] {{Green Movement}} {{Iranian presidential election, 2009 footer}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Death Of Neda Agha-Soltan}} [[Category:Deaths by person|Agha-Soltan, Neda]] [[Category:Iranian presidential election, 2009]] [[Category:Filmed killings|Agha-Soltan, Neda]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Iran]] [[Category:History of the Islamic Republic of Iran]] [[Category:Political repression in Iran]] [[Category:Islamic Azad University alumni]] [[Category:June 2009 events]] [[Category:2009 in Iran]] [[Category:2009 in women's history]] [[Category:21st century in Tehran]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use British English|date=October 2013}} '''Debbie Purdy''' (4 May 1963 – 23 December 2014)<ref name=ind>{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/debbie-purdy-campaigner-who-fought-tirelessly-for-clarification-of-assisted-suicide-laws-9950559.html |title= Debbie Purdy: Campaigner who fought tirelessly for clarification of assisted suicide laws |date= 30 December 2014 |accessdate= 30 December 2014 |first= Marcus |last= Williamson |work= The Independent}}</ref> was a British music journalist<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2009/aug/02/debbie-purdy-assisted-suicide-omari-puente</ref> and political activist from [[Bradford]], [[West Yorkshire]], with primary progressive [[multiple sclerosis]], notable for her challenge to the [[English law|law]] in [[England and Wales]] as relates to [[assisted suicide]].<ref name="HouseLords">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/lawreports/joshuarozenberg/3098209/Popular-QC-appointed-to-House-of-Lords.html|title=Popular QC appointed to House of Lords|work=Telegraph | accessdate=2008-09-29 | location=London | first=Joshua | last=Rozenberg | date=2008-09-29}}</ref> On 20 September 2009, it was announced that guidelines on assisted suicide law would be published by the UK Government. The guidelines for England and Wales "come after a legal battle won by Debbie Purdy", as "Law Lords accepted earlier this year that [Purdy] had a right to know whether her husband would be prosecuted if he helped her to travel abroad to commit suicide."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8265304.stm|title= New guidance on assisted suicide|work=BBC News | accessdate=2009-09-20 | date=2009-09-20}}</ref>
==Purdy's case== Debbie Purdy and her counsel [[David Pannick]] QC argued that the [[Director of Public Prosecutions]] ([[Ken Macdonald]] QC) was infringing on her human rights by failing to clarify how the [[Suicide Act 1961]] is enforced.<ref name=HouseLords/> The DPP counsel took the position that the law does not require the DPP to make any further clarification of the Act: they argue that the Act and further information contained in the [[Code for Crown Prosecutors]] provide sufficient information.
Purdy's particular concern was to discover if any actions her husband, [[Omar Puente]], took in assisting her suicide would lead to his prosecution.<ref name=HouseLords/> The penalty for those who "aid, abet, counsel or procure the suicide of another" is a maximum of 14 years.<ref name="DontJail">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/dont-jail-my-husband-if-he-helps-me-to-die-pleads-ms-sufferer-927090.html|title= Don't jail my husband if he helps me to die, pleads MS sufferer|work=The Independent | accessdate=2008-09-12 | location=London | date=2008-09-12}}</ref> No family member of the 92 Britons who have gone abroad for an assisted suicide has been prosecuted but some have been charged and have had to wait for months before hearing the charges have been dropped.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/oct/13/death-assistedsuicide|title= Dying for guidance|work=The Guardian | accessdate=2008-10-13 | location=London | first=Yvonne | last=Roberts | date=2008-10-13}}</ref> Purdy said that if her husband would be exposed to prosecution for helping her travel to [[Switzerland]] to a [[Dignitas (euthanasia group)|Dignitas]] clinic to die, she would make the journey sooner whilst she was able to travel unassisted.<ref name="LaunchesCase">{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/latest/2008/10/02/ms-sufferer-launches-assisted-suicide-case-115875-20766954/|title= MS sufferer launches assisted suicide case|work=Mirror| accessdate=2008-10-02}}</ref> This would save her husband from exposure to the law but would have forced Purdy to make her decision on dying before she felt it was absolutely necessary.<ref name=LaunchesCase/>
The hearing began on 2 October 2008 and was complete soon after. The venue was the [[High Court of Justice]]. It proceeded before [[Lord Justice]] [[Scott Baker (judge)|Scott Baker]] and Mr [[Justice Aikens]]. In court the DPP said that Purdy could not be given any reassurance that her husband would not be prosecuted as the law was clear that assisting suicide is an offence.
On 10 December 2008 [[British Sky Broadcasting|Sky TV]] broadcast a programme on which a man with [[motor neurone disease]] was shown committing suicide with assistance.<ref name="ReferenceA">BBC Newsnight: TX 10 December 2008</ref> There had also been the UK case of a Mr James who went to Switzerland with the aid of his parents after being paralysed whilst playing [[rugby (sport)|rugby]] and the Department of Public Prosecutions determined that to prosecute the parents would be against the public interest.<ref name="ReferenceA" /> These two events led to the issue of assisted suicide making the first story on the [[BBC]]'s ''[[Newsnight]]''. Purdy appeared to debate the issue and denied that it is society that makes disabled people wish to kill themselves and reasserted her belief that it is right to be able to seek assistance when one is physically incapable of committing suicide oneself.<ref name="ReferenceA" />
==Personal life== Purdy met her husband [[Omar Puente]] in Singapore when he was playing with a band,<ref name=DontJail/> and they married in 1998.<ref name=ind/> She was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis after she found her feet felt heavy when out dancing. She later used a wheelchair for mobility and both her sight and hearing began to deteriorate.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/3089249/Right-to-die-campaigner-Debbie-Purdy-vows-to-take-fight-to-House-of-Lords.html|title=Right-to-die campaigner Debbie Purdy vows to take fight to House of Lords MS sufferer launches assisted suicide case|work=Telegraph| accessdate=2008-10-02 | location=London | first1=David | last1=Barrett | date=2008-09-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/the_way_we_live/article4836537.ece|title=The way we live|work=TimesOnline| accessdate=2008-10-02 | location=London | first=Margarette | last=Driscoll | date=2008-09-28}}</ref> Purdy entered the [[Marie Curie Hospice]] in [[Bradford]] in June 2013 and in December 2013 she began to intermittently refuse food. She described the length of time it was taking to die as "agonising".<ref>{{cite web |title=Debbie Purdy: Right-to-die campaigner dies |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leeds-25741005 |website=BBC |accessdate=21 September 2018}}</ref> Purdy died on 23 December 2014, aged 51.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leeds-30626698 |title= Debbie Purdy: Right-to-die campaigner's battle |date= 29 December 2014 |accessdate= 29 December 2014 |work= BBC News}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Dennis Hof |image = Dennis Hof, Heidi Fleiss, Ron Jeremy (cropped).jpg |caption = Dennis Hof at the 2006 Adult Video Network Convention in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] |partner = [[Heidi Fleiss]] |birth_date = {{birth date|mf=yes|1946|10|14}} |birth_place = [[Phoenix, Arizona]], U.S.In episode 3 of season 2 of "Cathouse", Hof mentions that he was born and raised in Phoenix. |death_date= {{death date and age|2018|10|16|1946|10|14}} |death_place = [[Crystal, Nye County|Crystal]], [[Nevada]], U.S. |occupation = [[Brothel]] [[owner]], [[television personality]], [[restaurateur]], [[politician]] |nationality = [[Americans|American]] |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] (2016–2018)
[[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] (2015–2016) |residence = |parents = |salary = |networth = |website = {{official website}} }} '''Dennis Hof''' (October 14, 1946 – October 16, 2018) was an [[United States|American]] [[brothel]] owner, entrepreneur, restaurateur, politician and star of the [[HBO]] series [[Cathouse: The Series|''Cathouse'']]. He was best known as the owner of seven [[Prostitution in Nevada|legal brothels]] in [[Nevada]]. Several of his brothels are in [[Moundhouse, Nevada]], a few minutes outside [[Carson City, Nevada|Carson City]]. His best-known brothel is the [[Moonlite BunnyRanch]]. Hof wrote an autobiography, ''The Art Of The Pimp''. He was posthumously elected to the [[Nevada Assembly]] less than one month after his death.{{cite news |last1=Price |first1=Michelle L. |title=A Dead Nevada Brothel Owner Won His Election Tuesday Night |url=http://time.com/5447734/dead-nevada-brothel-owner-won-election/ |accessdate=2018-11-09 |work=Time |date=2018-11-07}} ==Career== Hof owned gas stations, first in Arizona and later in Nevada, before going into the brothel business.{{cite news |last1=Fortin |first1=Jacey |title=Dennis Hof, the Pimp Who Won a Nevada State Primary, Dies at 72 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/16/us/dennis-hof-dead-brothel-nevada.html |accessdate=2018-10-20 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2018-10-16}} ===The Moonlite Bunny Ranch=== {{main page|Moonlite BunnyRanch}} Hof purchased and remodeled The Moonlite BunnyRanch in 1992, which had been founded in 1955; he then purchased a second brothel, Kitty's, and renamed it The Love Ranch North. Hof purchased two additional brothels from longtime [[Nye County]] brothel proprietor Joe Richards: the Cherry Patch in Crystal, Nevada, renamed the Love Ranch Vegas, and the Cherry Patch II in [[Amargosa Valley, Nevada]], renamed the Alien Cathouse. On September 8, 2018, it was announced that the Alien Cathouse had been sold to business owner Raman Sharma.{{cite news |url=https://nevadabrothels.co/alien-cathouse-has-a-new-owner/ |title=Alien Cathouse Has A New Owner {{!}} Nevada Brothels |date=September 9, 2018 |work=Nevada Brothels |access-date=September 13, 2018 |language=en-US}} In contrast to other Nevada brothel owners, who prefer to keep a low profile,{{citation needed|date=January 2008}} and despite Nevada laws banning brothel advertising,"Unlawful advertising of prostitution", [http://www.leg.state.nv.us/NRS/NRS-201.html#NRS201Sec430 NRS 201.430 and 201.440] Hof maintained a high profile to create publicity for his brothels{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Business/Economy/story?id=6815445&page=1|title=Rough Recession Tests Brothel Boundaries|author=ABC News|work=ABC News|accessdate=October 14, 2015|date=February 9, 2009}} A gregarious man, Hof was the president of the [[Nevada Brothel Owners' Association]], and its lobbyist; the Bunny Ranch is the closest brothel to the state capital, [[Carson City, Nevada|Carson City]]. Hof operated a website;{{cite web|url=http://www.bunnyranch.com/main.php|title=Official Bunny Ranch Homepage – Bunny Ranch Girls Pics and Videos – BunnyRanch in Las Vegas|work=bunnyranch.com|accessdate=October 14, 2015}} the "working girls" are encouraged to cultivate online relationships with both potential and past clients. He often appeared on talk shows, including Oprah Winfrey, The Today Show, The View, Fox News, Howard Stern, Lex and Terry, and many others. Hof employed [[porn stars|adult film stars]], including [[Sunset Thomas]] with whom he also had a romantic relationship.{{cite web |url=http://lasvegassun.com/blogs/kats-report/2013/jun/17/suit-against-sunset-thomas-offers-new-wrinkle-olde/ |title=Suit against Sunset Thomas offers new wrinkle in the oldest profession |author=John Katsilometes |work=LasVegasSun.com |accessdate=October 14, 2015 |date=June 17, 2013}} He also gave free offers to soldiers returning from duty.{{cite news |title=Nevada brothel offers free sex to returning troops |url=http://www.cnn.com/2003/US/West/06/03/offbeat.brothel.reut/ |accessdate=October 14, 2015 |work=[[Reuters]] |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=June 3, 2003}} In early 2009, due to [[Late 2000s recession|the recession]], State Senator [[Bob Coffin]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]) proposed legalizing prostitution statewide for tax purposes. Hof was prominently featured in a number of media reports saying he would expand into [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] given the opportunity, and was looking at some closed casinos as property.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} However, the [[Nevada]] lawmakers chose not to consider the proposal of statewide legal prostitution during that legislative session.[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29181044/ MSNBC] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215202936/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29181044/ |date=February 15, 2009}} ====Series==== Hof and the Moonlite Bunny Ranch brothel were featured in the HBO series ''[[Cathouse: The Series|Cathouse]]'', which ran from 2002 to 2014.{{IMDb title|id=0359056|title=Cathouse (2002)}} Two documentary series followed: ''[[Cathouse: The Series]]''{{IMDb title|id=0472944|title=Cathouse: The Series}} premiered in 2005, and ''[[Cathouse 2: Back in the Saddle]]''{{IMDb title|id=0395496|title=Cathouse: Back in the Saddle}} appeared in 2007. Hof also was the producer of the Showtime series ''Working Girls in Bed''.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} Both featured a look at the inner workings of a legal house of prostitution as well as the life of a number of the working girls, borrowing some techniques from [[reality television]], such as camera-only interviews and staged spontaneity. ===Filmography=== Hof appears as himself in an "underground" mall shop called "Pro-Life Sex" in the 2014 indie film ''Alongside Night''.{{IMDb title|id=1667061|title=Alongside Night}} In 1998 Hof was in the [[Hughes Brothers]] documentary ''[[American Pimp]]'' where notably he was the only caucasian the brothers interviewed. At one point in the documentary he very nearly accurately predicted his own death, ''going out getting the best piece of pussy''.''American Pimp'' IMDb.com ===Public speaking and television appearances=== Hof had speaking engagements at [[Oxford University]]{{cite web |url=http://www.details.com/story/dennis-hof-bunny-ranch-cathouse-interview |title=Inside Dennis Hof's Moonlite Bunny Ranch, the World's Most Famous Brothel |author=Jennifer M. Wood |date= |work=Details |accessdate=January 14, 2016}} and [[Trinity College, Dublin]].{{cite news |last1=Skorupa |first1=Susan |title='The Art of the Pimp': Dennis Hof tells all |url=http://www.rgj.com/story/life/2015/06/19/dennis-hof-moonlite-bunny-ranch-brothels-nevada/28982057/ |accessdate=October 14, 2015 |work=[[Reno Gazette-Journal]] |date=June 19, 2015}}{{cite web |url=https://www.vice.com/read/bunny-ranch-owner-dennis-hof-is-running-for-senate-to-end-sex-trafficking-678 |title=Bunny Ranch Pimp Dennis Hof Wants to Run for Senate to End Sex Trafficking |work=VICE |accessdate=October 14, 2015 |date=July 20, 2015}} ''[[The New Yorker]]'' ran an 11-page article by Rebecca Mead about him, entitled "American Pimp", in 2001.{{cite journal |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2001/04/23/american-pimp |title=American Pimp |author=Rebecca Mead |date=April 23, 2001 |journal=The New Yorker |accessdate=October 14, 2015}} Hof appeared on Walton and Johnson, ''[[Brand X with Russell Brand]]'', ''[[Rover's Morning Glory]]'', ''[[The Johnny Dare Morning Show]]'', ''[[The Todd and Tyler Radio Empire|Todd and Tyler]]'', ''[[American Pimp]]'', ''[[The Tyra Banks Show]]'', [[Lex and Terry]], the ''[[Opie and Anthony Show]]'', ''[[The Adam Carolla Show (radio)|The Adam Carolla Show]]'',{{cite web |last1=Laxamana |first1=Chris |title=Dennis Hof and Jo Koy |url=http://adamcarolla.com/dennis-hof-and-jo-koy/ |website=The Adam Carolla Show |accessdate=October 16, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170502083511/http://adamcarolla.com/dennis-hof-and-jo-koy/ |archivedate=May 2, 2017 |date=May 18, 2015}} ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'', The Mike Calta Show, Loveline with Stryker and Dr. Drew, Derek and Romaine, and on ''[[Dr. Phil (TV series)|Dr. Phil]]'', as well as giving a tour and interview to conservative pundit [[Sean Hannity]] on ''[[Hannity and Colmes]]''. ===Author=== Hof released a book, ''The Art of the Pimp'', in March 2015. The memoir includes personal accounts from women who worked for him, in which they detail sexual abuse at his hands. It also includes a psychological profile of Hof from psychotherapist Dr. Sheenah Hankin. Dr. Hankin found him to be a narcissist with no empathy, and states of his relationships with his employees, "Like any pimp, he exploits them. This is sadistic behavior, and it is both unrecognized and denied."{{cite web |url=https://nypost.com/2015/03/08/the-bizarre-memoir-of-americas-most-famous-legal-brothel/ |title=The bizarre memoir of America's most famous pimp |work=The New York Post |accessdate=June 27, 2018 |date=March 8, 2015}} ==Legal troubles== In 1999, Lyon County sheriff's deputy Brian Putzer filed a police report accusing Hof of death threats.{{cite web |url=https://thenevadaindependent.com/article/former-prostitutes-allege-unwelcome-sexual-contact-from-brothel-owner-dennis-hof |title=Former prostitutes allege unwelcome sexual contact from brothel owner Dennis Hof |work=The Nevada Independent |accessdate=June 27, 2018}} According to Deputy Putzer, the threats were spurred when Putzer did a routine walk-through check of one of Hof's brothels and discovered documents showing that Hof was setting up sexual encounters in counties where prostitution is illegal. Putzer states that his superiors "didn't want to challenge Hof" as the county is poorly funded and Hof's brothels were a major contributor to the local economy. In 2016, a woman who had formerly worked for Hof, Jennifer O'Kane, publicly accused Hof of nonconsensual sexual contact, rape, sexual harassment, and having sex with his workers without a condom. O'Kane stated that Hof regularly gets away with the sexual abuse of his employees due to their status as sex workers, and that she had reported the rape to the D.A.'s office in 2011, but nothing had been pursued. The accusations were similar to statements made in Hof's own memoir by former Hof employees Krissy Summers and Cami Parker, who noted abusive behavior and coerced sexual encounters in the brothel. A detective interviewed O'Kane regarding the accusations but charges were not pursued as there were no other direct witnesses and Hof was running for political office at the time. Deputy District Attorney Katrina Samuels again declined to prosecute the case in 2018, stating that the statute of limitations had passed. In December 2017, another former employee, Diana Grandmaison, reported a non-consensual sexual encounter with Hof to the same detective who had investigated the O'Kane case. Grandmaison stated that Hof regularly initiated such encounters with the young girls who worked for him and detailed other forms of work abuse. No further action was taken. ==Politics== Hof endorsed [[Ron Paul]] in the 2008 and 2012 presidential elections.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/21973236/ns/politics-decision_08/t/ron-paul-endorsed-nevada-brothel-owner/|title=Ron Paul endorsed by Nevada brothel owner|work=msnbc.com|accessdate=October 14, 2015|date=November 26, 2007}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/01/03/moonlite-bunnyranch-endorses-ron-paul_n_1181575.html|title=The Moonlite BunnyRanch Endorses Ron Paul For President|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=October 14, 2015|date=January 3, 2012}} He joined the [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]] in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/politics/elections/nevada-brothel-owner-says-he-might-run-us-senate|title=Nevada brothel owner says he might run for U.S. Senate|author=BEN BOTKIN LAS VEGAS REVIEW-JOURNAL|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|accessdate=October 14, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2015/07/09/the-libertarian-party-is-supporting-a-brothel-owner-and-yes-it-supports-legal-prostitution/|title=The Libertarian Party is backing a brothel owner. And yes, it supports legal prostitution.|author=Amber Phillips|date=July 9, 2015|work=Washington Post|accessdate=October 14, 2015}} In December 2016, he became a "Trump Republican".{{cite web|url=http://www.dennishof.com/hof-bolts-libertarians-joins-trumps-republicans/|title=Hof Bolts Libertarians, Joins Trump's Republicans|author=Richard Hunter|date=December 7, 2016|work=Press Release|accessdate=April 10, 2017}} In 2016 and 2018, he ran for a seat in the Nevada state legislature, the former as a Libertarian and the latter as a Republican; he lost the first race to [[James Oscarson]] but beat him in the GOP primary in 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/amphtml/finance/news/legal-pimp-defeats-nevada-lawmaker-070355548.html|title=Nevada pimp wins GOP primary, rejoices with Hollywood madam|website=www.yahoo.com}} He prevailed in the primary after Nye County officials attempted to remove Hof's campaign signs. However, in an emergency motion before the Federal District of Nevada, Hof prevailed in a First Amendment claim against the county.{{cite web|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/federal-judge-orders-nye-county-to-return-hofs-political-sign/|title=Federal judge orders Nye County to return Hof's political sign|date=June 12, 2018|publisher=}} He was represented in that matter by First Amendment attorney, [[Marc Randazza]].{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}. After winning the primary Hof styled himself as the "Trump from Pahrump."{{cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/24/politics/dennis-hof-nevada-brothel-owner-trump/index.html|title=CNN: 'I'm riding the Trump wave. He's Christopher Columbus,' says Nevada pimp running for office|accessdate=June 27, 2018}} At the time of his death, Hof was running for the [[Nevada Assembly]]'s 36th District. Hof, whose name remained on the ballot (with polling places posting public signage stating that Hof was deceased), posthumously won election to the seat over his Democratic opponent, Lesia Romanov, by a 68.3 to 31.7 percent margin; under the laws of the state of Nevada, the seat will be declared vacant.{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2018/11/07/dead-brothel-owner-dennis-hof-wins-nevada-election/|title=Voters choose dead pimp over Democratic opponent|first=Joe|last=Tacopino|work=The New York Post|date=November 7, 2018|accessdate=November 7, 2018}} County commissioners from Lincoln, Nye and Clark counties will conduct a weighted vote to determine Hof's replacement.{{cite web|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/dennis-hof-deceased-brothel-owner-wins-nevada-assembly-race-1521112/|title=Dennis Hof, deceased brothel owner, wins Nevada Assembly race|date=November 7, 2018|publisher=}} ==Personal life== In ''Cathouse: The Musical'', Hof revealed that he only dated prostitutes. "I don't date civilians [non-working girls]." The documentary series showed several of his relationships with employees, such as adult film star [[Sunset Thomas]]''[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1171227/ Cathouse: The Musical]'' and [[Heidi Fleiss]].{{cite web|url=http://www.esquire.com/entertainment/books/a33930/Dennis-hof-book-interview/|title=Dennis Hof Interview - Dennis Hof on 'The Art of the Pimp'|author=Kenny Herzog|work=Esquire|accessdate=October 14, 2015|date=March 26, 2015}} In his memoir, Hof disclosed a lack of interest in monogamy and detailed how every one of his relationships ended due to his own infidelity. Hof was a close friend of Fox News personality [[Tucker Carlson]]. He once stated that he communicated with Carlson daily to give him ideas for his show.{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/features/dennis-hof-tucker-carlson-w521499/|title=A Wild Conversation with the 'Pimp' Who Won a Nevada Primary|work=Rolling Stone|accessdate=June 27, 2018|date=June 13, 2018}} ==Death== Hof died in his sleep at his [[Dennis Hof's Love Ranch|Love Ranch South]] in Crystal, Nevada, on October 16, 2018, following a party for his 72nd birthday that had been attended by [[Joe Arpaio]], Heidi Fleiss,{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/amphtml/entertainment/dennis-hof-dies-72-spent-final-hours-ron-jeremy-heidi-fleiss-recognizable-names-002852978.html|title=Dennis Hof dies at 72: He spent his final hours with Ron Jeremy, Heidi Fleiss, and other recognizable names|website=www.yahoo.com}} [[Grover Norquist]] and [[Ron Jeremy]], the last of whom found Hof unresponsive.{{cite web |last1=Duggan |first1=Brian |last2=Damon |first2=Anjeanette |last3=Spillman |first3=Benjamin |last4=DeHaven |first4=James |title=Dennis Hof, Nevada's bombastic legal pimp and Assembly candidate, has died |url=https://eu.rgj.com/story/news/2018/10/16/dennis-hof-pimp-and-legislative-candidate-nevada-dead/1661304002/ |publisher=Reno Gazette Journal |accessdate=October 16, 2018 |date=October 16, 2018}} Police did not suspect foul play at the time of his death, and no one who was with him the night before noticed any signs of ill-health. Hof's legislature campaign manager Chuck Muth said that Hof was "having the time of his life" that night.{{cite web|url=https://www.nypost.com/2018/10/16/gop-candidate-brothel-owner-dennis-hof-found-dead/amp/|title=Brothel owner-turned-politician Dennis Hof found dead at Love Ranch|date=October 16, 2018|publisher=}} ==See also== * [[Prostitution in Nevada]] {{Portalbar|Biography|Books|Nevada|Television}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{official website}} * [https://www.dennishof.com/ Campaign website] * {{IMDb name|1348053}} * 2 findagrave memorials, one stating his cadaver has already been cremated: [https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/194038376/dennis-hof memorial #1],...[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/194022804/dennis-l-hof memorial #2] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hof, Dennis}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:American brothel owners and madams]] [[Category:American pimps]] [[Category:Brothels in Nevada]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Phoenix, Arizona]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Nevada]] [[Category:Members of the Nevada Assembly]] [[Category:Nevada Libertarians]] [[Category:Nevada Republicans]] [[Category:People from Carson City, Nevada]] [[Category:Politicians elected posthumously]] [[Category:Politicians from Phoenix, Arizona]] [[Category:Prostitution in Nevada]] [[Category:Writers from Nevada]] [[Category:Writers from Phoenix, Arizona]] [[Category:American sex industry businesspeople]]

{{Infobox royalty | name =Duchess Frederica | title = Princess of Holstein-Gottorp | image = Johann-Baptist Lampi d. Ä. 006-2.jpg | caption = | spouse =[[Peter I, Grand Duke of Oldenburg|Prince Peter Frederick Louis of Holstein-Gottorp]] | issue =[[Augustus, Grand Duke of Oldenburg]]
[[Duke George of Oldenburg]] | full name ={{lang-de|Friederike Elisabeth Amalie Auguste}} | house =[[House of Württemberg|Württemberg]] | father =[[Frederick II Eugene, Duke of Württemberg]] | mother =[[Friederike Dorothea of Brandenburg-Schwedt]] | birth_date ={{birth date|1765|7|27|df=y}} | birth_place =[[Trzebiatów|Treptow an der Rega]], [[Province of Pomerania (1653-1815)|Province of Pomerania]], [[Prussia]] | death_date ={{death date and age|1785|11|24|1765|7|27|df=y}} | death_place =[[Vienna]], [[Austria]] | religion = [[Lutheranism]] |}} '''Duchess Frederica of Württemberg''' ({{lang-de|Friederike Elisabeth Amalie Auguste von Württemberg}}; 27 July 1765 – 24 November 1785) was a daughter of [[Frederick II Eugene, Duke of Württemberg]] and [[Friederike Dorothea of Brandenburg-Schwedt]]. ==Family== Frederica was born on 27 July 1765 in [[Treptow an der Rega]], [[Farther Pomerania]] (now [[Trzebiatów]], [[Poland]]) as the seventh child and second daughter of [[Frederick II Eugene, Duke of Württemberg]] and his wife [[Friederike Dorothea of Brandenburg-Schwedt]].{{Cite web | last = Lundy | first = Darryl | title = The Peerage: Friederike Herzogin von Württemberg | url=http://thepeerage.com/p11043.htm#i110430 | accessdate = 16 December 2009 }} Among her siblings were [[Frederick of Württemberg|King Frederick of Württemberg]], [[Sophie Dorothea of Württemberg|Sophia Dorothea, Empress of Russia]], and [[Duchess Elisabeth of Württemberg|Elisabeth, Archduchess of Austria]]. Frederica's paternal grandparents were [[Karl Alexander, Duke of Württemberg]] and [[Maria Augusta of Thurn and Taxis]]. Her maternal grandparents were [[Margrave Frederick William of Brandenburg-Schwedt]] and [[Princess Sophia Dorothea of Prussia]], sister of [[Frederick the Great]]. ==Marriage and issue== On 6 June 1781, Frederica married [[Peter I, Grand Duke of Oldenburg|Prince Peter Frederick of Holstein-Gottorp]]. The marriage was meant to strengthen relations between Russia and Württemberg (Frederica's sister was married to [[Paul I of Russia]], a member of the [[House of Holstein-Gottorp]]). They had two sons: [[Augustus, Grand Duke of Oldenburg|Augustus]] (born in 1783) and [[Duke George of Oldenburg|George]] (born in 1784). ==Death== At the age of twenty, Frederica died from childbirth in [[Vienna]] on 24 November 1785. Her widowed husband Peter never remarried. He would succeed his cousin [[William, Duke of Oldenburg|William]] as [[Grand Duke of Oldenburg]] in 1823, many years after Frederica's death. ==Issue== [[File:Grand PrinceAugust Oldenburg and Prince GeorgofOldenburg.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Frederica's two surviving sons: [[Augustus, Grand Duke of Oldenburg|Augustus]] and [[Duke George of Oldenburg|George]] in the 1790s.]] {| class="wikitable sortable" |- bgcolor="#cccccc" !width="18%"|Name!! width="14%"|Birth!! width="14%"|Death!! width="62%"|Notes |- | [[Augustus, Grand Duke of Oldenburg|Paul Friedrich ''August'', Grand Duke of Oldenburg]] || 13 July 1783|| 27 February 1853|| married firstly [[Princess Adelheid of Anhalt-Bernburg-Schaumburg-Hoym]]; had issue, including [[Amalia of Oldenburg]] who became Queen consort of Greece;
secondly, he married [[Princess Ida of Anhalt-Bernburg-Schaumburg-Hoym]]; had issue;
thirdly, he married [[Princess Cecilia of Sweden (1807–1844)|Princess Cecilia of Sweden]]; had issue. |- | [[Duke George of Oldenburg|Duke ''Georg'' Peter Friedrich of Oldenburg]] || 9 May 1784 || 27 December 1812|| married [[Grand Duchess Catherine Pavlovna of Russia]]; had issue. |- |} {{clear}} ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center | boxstyle_1 = background-color: #fcc; | boxstyle_2 = background-color: #fb9; | boxstyle_3 = background-color: #ffc; | boxstyle_4 = background-color: #bfc; | boxstyle_5 = background-color: #9fe; | 1 = 1.
