Testing on the bones indicated the boy was either from the surrounding area, or possibly that he had lived in the Atlanta area or in northern Florida.{{cite news|title=Investigators Need Your Help Closing John Doe Case|url=http://www.wctv.tv/home/headlines/Investigators-Need-Your-Help-Closing-John-Doe-Case-292125821.html|accessdate=July 15, 2015|work=WCTV News|publisher=CBS|date=February 16, 2015}}{{cite web|title=John Doe 1999|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1105216/1/screen|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]]|accessdate=July 15, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Ove|first1=Justin|title=Decatur John Doe Remains Nameless 16 Years On|url=http://patch.com/georgia/decatur/decatur-john-doe-remains-nameless-16-years/|accessdate=July 15, 2015|work=Decatur-Avondale Estates Patch|publisher=Patch Media|date=February 17, 2015}} The cause of death is not known, and no suspects have been noted in the case; if foul play was involved, he appeared to be healthy when he died.{{cite news|last1=Markiewicz|first1=David|title=Public's help sought identifying boy found dead in DeKalb 16 years ago|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/news/publics-help-sought-identifying-boy-found-dead-in-/nkCWq/|accessdate=July 15, 2015|work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution|date=February 16, 2015}} It was previously speculated that the body belonged to D'Wan Sims, a child missing since 1994 from Michigan, before DNA testing in 2003 confirmed that Sims was not the John Doe.{{cite web|title=D'Wan Christian Sims|url=http://www.charleyproject.org/cases/s/sims_dwan.html|website=The Charley Project|accessdate=July 15, 2015|date=June 29, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150711094550/http://www.charleyproject.org/cases/s/sims_dwan.html|archive-date=July 11, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The case has also been featured on ''America's Most Wanted.''{{cite web|title=Case File: 217UMGA|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/217umga.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=July 15, 2015|date=January 5, 2012}} ==Illinois== {{anchor|Will County Jane Doe (1981)}} ===Will County Jane Doe (1981)=== [[File:Will County, Illinois Jane Doe.jpg|thumb|150px|FBI sculpture of the 1981 Will County Jane Doe]] The remains of a white woman were found on April 19, 1981 in [[New Lenox, Illinois|New Lenox]], Will County, Illinois, along [[interstate 80]]. The female was between twenty-three and thirty-five years old and was presumed to have died about a year before she was found. Because she was badly decomposed, it was not possible to estimate her eye or hair color, along with her weight. It was possible to determine her height, which was likely around {{convert|5|ft|5|in|cm|spell=in}}. No clothing or other items were located at the scene. The woman had suffered a fracture to her nose at some point during life, as evidence of such an injury was found when examining the skull. Her DNA has since been processed and nearly 250 people have been excluded from the case.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 3153|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/3153|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 13, 2015}} {{anchor|Bloomington Jane Doe}} ===Bloomington Jane Doe=== [[File:273UFIL Recon 003.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Bloomington Jane Doe]] A woman's body was found hanging on a telephone pole on February 2, 1982 in Bloomington, Illinois. She was between twenty-five and forty years old. Her hair was black, but was beginning to turn gray. She was {{convert|5|ft|1|in|cm|spell=in}} tall and weighed around {{convert|140|lb|kg}} and was believed to be a smoker, as the autopsy suggested. She was seen alive before her death by people who stated she was not "mentally stable."{{cite web|title=Case File 273UFIL|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/273ufil.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=December 29, 2014|date=August 30, 2011}} {{anchor|Cook County Jane Doe}} ===Cook County Jane Doe (2005)=== [[File:Cook County Jane Doe (2005).jpg|thumb|150px|2005 Cook County Jane Doe]] In Chicago, Illinois, the skeleton of a female twelve to eighteen years old was located on April 28, 2005. She had been found near a railroad and had died several years earlier, possibly up to eight years prior. Because of the condition of her remains, her height, hair color and weight could not be estimated. The female's height was possible to be determined, however, and was subsequently placed between five feet and five feet five inches (152–165 cm). Some teeth were not found in the skull, but no evidence of dental work was noted. Examination of the bones indicated she was white with possible Asian ancestry.{{cite web|title=Jane Doe 2005|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1204842/1/screen|website=misssingkids.com|publisher=[[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]]|accessdate=July 19, 2015}} Five missing people have been excluded as possible identities of the subject.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 10693|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/10693|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 19, 2015|date=October 17, 2012}} ==Louisiana== {{anchor|Rapides Parish Jane Doe}} ===Rapides Parish Jane Doe (1980)=== {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [http://identifyla.lsu.edu/peopleimages/320_1.jpg FACES reconstruction] | image2 = [http://doenetwork.org/cases/images/65UFLA.jpg 3D reconstruction] | image3 = [http://doenetwork.org/cases/images/65UFLA1.jpg 3D reconstruction (profile)] }} On November 5, 1980, the partial skeleton of a young white female was found by a hunter in Rapides Parish, Louisiana.{{cite web|title=Case #80-05|url=http://identifyla.lsu.edu/profile.php?id=320|website=identifyla.lsu.edu|publisher=FACES|accessdate=November 6, 2014}} The victim, aged fifteen to nineteen, was approximately five feet to five feet five inches tall (152–165 cm); her weight could not be estimated. She had received dental care, as some fillings were found in the teeth of the skull.{{cite web|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1184278/1#poster|title=Have you seen this child? JANE DOE1980|work=missingkids.org}} The skeleton of a dog was also found near the Jane Doe, but it is not possible to confirm if it was hers. A local man stated he had shot the dog but did not know of the victim's presence at the scene. A pair of gray, cotton wool socks were the only clothing found at the scene.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 1879|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/1879|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=November 6, 2014|date=June 2, 2008}} Shoulder-length brown hair was also found near the body, which was presumed to be the victim's. Her remains may have been at the location from two months to two and a half years and one or both of her hands and limbs were never found. Her cause of death has never been determined.{{cite web|title=Case File 65UFLA|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/65ufla.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=November 6, 2014}} ===Belle Chasse John Doe=== On February 14, 1975, a teenage boy was found dead in Belle Chasse, Louisiana. He committed suicide by hanging himself with a bed sheet from a persimmon tree. He was about 16 or 17 years old and wore yellow and maroon shirt, blue pants, mismatched socks and no shoes. Leaning against the tree was a jar filled with his 4-page suicide note. ==Maine== {{anchor|Alfred Jake Fuller}} ==="Alfred Jake Fuller"=== A man aged 40 to 46 was discovered in a hotel room, not long after his death on May 2, 2014. He registered under the name "Alfred Jake Fuller" and provided a birth date of November 8, 1970. No records were found to match this information, leading investigators to speculate he used an alias. The man was estimated to be 5'10" at a weight of 255 pounds. He wore a short goatee and had curly brown hair. A blue "discoloration was on the left side of his face and a large nevus was in between his shoulders. His personal items included a prepaid [[Visa Inc.|Visa]] card and a "fugitive recovery agent" document. He was fully clothed and wore two pieces of jewelry on his neck.{{cite web |title=NamUs #UP15432 |url=https://www.namus.gov/UnidentifiedPersons/Case#/15432/details |website=www.namus.gov |publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]] |accessdate=24 October 2018 |language=en |date=1 July 2016}} ==Maryland== {{anchor|Prince George's County John Doe (1973)}} ===Prince George's County John Doe (1973)=== [[File:NamUs UP 4833 Reconstruction 001.jpg|thumb|150px|left|1973 Prince George's County John Doe]] A young man was found on December 6, 1973 in Upper Marlboro, Prince George's County, Maryland. He was believed to have been between fifteen and twenty years old. The cause of his death could not be determined. He was five feet tall (152 cm) and weighed {{convert|105|lb|kg}}, which is short for a male his age. He had died within hours of his body being discovered in a wooded area, near a highway. The decedent may have been in a hospital for undisclosed reasons. He had brown hair and brown eyes as well as a thin mustache. He was found wearing a green sweatshirt, gray and white pants, white underwear, socks, boots and a brown belt. On his pants, the word "shalom" was written with poor penmanship, along with other words.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 4833|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/4833|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=December 29, 2014|date=February 13, 2009}} {{anchor|Baltimore County Jane Doe (1987}} ===Baltimore City Jane Doe (1987)=== A woman was found in an alley on June 16, 1987 in Baltimore, Maryland. She was seen previously being dropped off at a nearby residence. She was still alive when she was found, but died the next day at a hospital. The woman was between the ages of twenty-four and thirty and had a distinct tattoo of the name Curtis Lee accompanied by a turtle. She was five feet six inches tall (168 cm) and weighed {{convert|138|lb|kg}} with green eyes, freckles and short red hair.{{cite web|date=June 24, 2009|title=NamUs UP # 5439|url=https://identifyus.org/en/cases/5439|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=January 3, 2015}} A scar from a needle was found on her neck and she also had another scar on her lower abdomen. The woman wore a ring, underwear and jeans with a belt. Also in her possession were a business card, an opened pack of cigarettes and a key on a key ring. Despite the suspicious circumstances, her cause of death has not been published.{{cite web|title=Case File 464UFMD|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/464ufmd.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=January 3, 2015}} ==Massachusetts== {{anchor|Norfolk County Jane Doe}} ===Norfolk County Jane Doe=== [[File:Plainville, Massachusetts Jane Doe facial reconstruction.jpg|thumb|150px|left|The Norfolk County Jane Doe may have been biracial.]] The skeletonized [[skull]] and [[torso]] of a female of [[Sub-Saharan African]] heritage, possibly [[biracial]], was discovered on August 8, 2004 in [[Plainville, Massachusetts|Plainville]], [[Norfolk County, Massachusetts]]. The cause of her death was not apparent, but the decedent was wrapped in a blanket and buried in a shallow grave near a truck stop. She had been at that location anywhere from three to ten years prior.{{cite web| title=Who is She???|website=Massachusetts Cold Cases|url=http://www.ctcoldcases.com/Massachusetts.html |accessdate=May 11, 2014}} She stood between four feet nine and five feet three inches tall (145–160 cm) and was between twenty-five and thirty-five years old.{{cite web |accessdate=April 30, 2014| title=Massachusetts Jane Doe |url=http://www.hellbeasts.com/?p=4747| date=July 12, 2013}}{{cite web| url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/578ufma.html| title=Case File 578UFMA| publisher=[[The Doe Network]] |accessdate=April 30, 2014}}{{cite web| url=http://unidentifiedremains.blogspot.com/2009/07/help-identify-jane-doe-black-female.html |title=Help Identify Jane Doe Black Female |date=July 22, 2009 |accessdate=April 30, 2014}} ==Michigan== ==="Bill"=== {{anchor|Bill (decedent)}} {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [https://web.archive.org/web/20141218001533/https://identifyus.org/en/medias/full/26605] }} After attending a party, a young woman was found unresponsive in Highland Park, Wayne County, Michigan on March 25, 1976. She had told others that her name was "Bill" and was a runaway from a group home in a different state, such as Ohio. Those she was with on the night of her death had known Bill for only a short time. She was approximately seventeen to twenty years old (although she may have been in a wider age range of fifteen to twenty-five) when she died and weighed {{convert|150|lb|kg}} at a height of {{convert|5|ft|8|in|cm|spell=in}}. She had no detectable dental work on her teeth and wore a pair of pants with a pattern of black and white squares, maroon socks, a black or dark gray shirt and a black bra.{{cite web|title=Jane Doe 1976|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1228213/1#poster|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]]|accessdate=December 17, 2014}} When Bill was found unresponsive, she was taken to a hospital where she was pronounced dead.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 12115|url=https://identifyus.org/en/cases/12115|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=December 17, 2014|date=February 3, 2014}} She had blueish-green eyes and shoulder length brown hair.{{cite web|title=Case File: 1195UFMI|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/1195ufmi.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=December 17, 2014|date=October 11, 2014}} Her body was exhumed in November 2014 to obtain DNA information.{{cite news|title=Bodies exhumed at Plymouth cemetery by police for DNA testing|url=http://www.myfoxdetroit.com/story/27342968/2-bodies-being-exhumed-at-plymouth-cemetery|accessdate=November 18, 2014|work=My Fox Detroit|agency=Fox News|date=November 10, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113154735/http://www.myfoxdetroit.com/story/27342968/2-bodies-being-exhumed-at-plymouth-cemetery|archivedate=November 13, 2014|df=mdy-all}} ==Minnesota== {{anchor|Ramsey County John Doe}} ===Ramsey County John Doe=== [[File:Saint Paul John Doe UP12123 Reconstruction 001d.jpg|thumb|150px|Ramsey County John Doe]] The body of a man was found on February 7, 1985 in St. Paul, Ramsey County, Minnesota. The man was {{convert|5|ft|9|in|cm|spell=in}} tall, {{convert|180|lb|kg}} and between twenty and forty years old when he died. His body was found in an abandoned building and clothed in multiple layers, indicating he was homeless. He had died weeks before, but was preserved due to the cold weather. He had brown hair as well as a beard and mustache. His eyes had decomposed to the point where their color could not be determined. His clothing included boots, a green shirt, brown gloves, a red scarf, an orange hat, a jacket with a camouflage design, a white jacket, a sweater and jeans. A duffel bag found with the corpse also had various items.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 12123|url=https://identifyus.org/en/cases/12123|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=December 29, 2014|date=February 4, 2014}} ==Mississippi== {{anchor|Hancock County Jane Doe}} ===Hancock County Jane Doe=== [[File:178ufms6 (4).jpg|150px|left|thumb|Hancock County Jane Doe]] A woman between thirty-seven and forty-two years old was struck by a vehicle and found on May 8, 1998 in Bay St. Louis, Hancock County, Mississippi. Initially, those who had hit the woman believed she was an animal, as it was late at night. She had suffered massive injuries across her body when she was struck. She was likely a transient, as she had tanned skin, unshaven legs and underarms, dirty nails and insect bites. Her nails were short, but she may have torn them instead of clipping, as they were uneven. The Jane Doe had no teeth and did not wear dentures when she was found. Her hair had been dyed several colors in the past and was a reddish color, but was naturally brown and wavy. She had variety of severe lung conditions as well as [[hydatid cysts]], which occurred parasitically. Her eyes were gray and she also had freckles.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 2841|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/2841|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=January 3, 2015|date=December 2, 2008}} The woman was five feet three to five feet five inches tall (160–165 cm) and weighed between {{convert|130|and|135|lb|kg|abbr=off}}. She was the mother of at least two children and had a cesarean section scar. She was drug-free, other than having seven caffeine pills found in her pocket. She wore a black sweatshirt, jeans and blue slippers. She had eaten french fries and pickles, as well as an unknown brownish liquid before her death, possibly from a fast-food restaurant or a diner. Permission was granted to exhume the woman's body in 2013, but her body was not at the site that was excavated.{{cite web|title=Case File: 178UFMS|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/178ufms.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=December 29, 2014|date=January 15, 2014}} ==Missouri== ===Little Jane Doe=== {{Main|St. Louis Jane Doe}} On February 23, 1983, the decapitated body of a young African American girl, aged 8–11, was found in the basement of an abandoned house in [[St. Louis]].{{cite news|last1=Perkarsky|first1=Michelle|title=Authorities try to locate body of girl, killed & beheaded 30 years ago|url=http://fox4kc.com/2013/06/17/authorities-try-to-locate-body-of-girl-killed-beheaded-30-years-ago/|accessdate=28 November 2014|work=Fox4KC|publisher=Fox|date=17 June 2013}} She is also known as "Hope" and "St. Louis Jane Doe." Her head has never been discovered, preventing identification via dental records. ==Nevada== {{anchor|Washoe County John Doe}} ===Washoe County John Doe=== [[File:0514-80 Reconstruction 002b.jpg|thumb|150px|1980 Washoe County John Doe]] A black male aged twenty-five to thirty-five crashed a vehicle into a guardrail on interstate 80 on July 16, 1980 in Washoe County, Nevada as he was fleeing from police at high speed after being pursued as a potential bank robbery suspect. The man was pronounced dead as he entered an emergency room. The victim was five feet three inches to five feet four inches tall (160–162 cm) and weighed {{convert|135|lb|kg}} and had black hair, brown eyes and a scar on his abdomen that appeared to have been long since healed.{{cite web|title=Case File 1417UMNV|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/1417umnv.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=July 7, 2015}} The victim also wore a beard and mustache and had been circumcised. Four missing men have been excluded from the case.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 2105|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/2105|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 7, 2015|date=June 15, 2008}} {{anchor|Clark County Jane Doe (1986)}} ===Clark County Jane Doe (1986)=== [[File:Nevada Cave-woman 005 Reconstruction Frontal.jpg|thumb|left|150px|1986 Clark County Jane Doe]] The mummified body of a woman aged twenty-five to thirty-five was discovered inside a mine shaft near the town of Antelope in Las Vegas, Clark County, Nevada on September 27, 1986. The subject was white, five feet six inches tall (168 cm) and weighed between {{convert|92|and|112|lb|kg|abbr=off}}. She appeared to be a transient, as the walls in the shaft were lined with wood and appeared to be a makeshift shelter.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 9027|url=https://identifyus.org/en/cases/9027|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 7, 2015|date=August 3, 2011}} She was discovered underneath a blanket, although she was naked. Several articles of clothing, a shirt, bra, a single sock and a pair of jeans as well as some personal items were found in or near the entrance, which included toothpaste, lip gloss and a pair of glasses. Examination of the body indicated she was a mother of at least one child and had had some dental work done. All of her adult teeth were intact. The cause of her death could not be determined.{{cite web|title=Case File 362UFNV|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/362ufnv.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=July 7, 2015|date=May 23, 2012}} {{anchor|Clark County John Doe}} ===Clark County John Doe=== [[File:87 0375b bg Reconstruction 003.jpg|thumb|150px|Clark County John Doe]] In his hotel room on February 16, 1987, a man was found dead after a drug overdose, presumed to have been accidental, in Las Vegas, Clark County, Nevada. He was estimated to have been between twenty-five and thirty-five years old and had brown hair and blue eyes. His clothing included a purple shirt, jeans, white socks and a brown belt. He had given the name of "Douglas Baker" with his address residing in the state of Florida, which turned out to be both an alias and a false address.{{cite web|title=Case File 257UMNV|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/257umnv.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=January 6, 2015}} He was {{convert|174|lb|kg}} at a height of six feet four inches tall (193 cm). He had "unusually long" fingers, which may be a way to identify him in the future.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 8137|url=https://identifyus.org/en/cases/8137|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=January 6, 2015|date=November 24, 2010}} {{anchor|Clark County Jane Doe (2008)}} ===Clark County Jane Doe (2008)=== {{distinguish|Arroyo Grande Jane Doe|Clark County Jane Doe (1980)|Sahara Sue}} On January 23, 2008, police received a letter with coordinates to a location in [[Henderson, Nevada|Henderson]], [[Clark County, Nevada]]. At the scene, a woman's [[skull]] was discovered along with a red patterned skirt. No other remains were found, which resulted in her weight and height being impossible to estimate.{{cite web| title=Unsolved Murder Spotlight: The Clark County Jane Doe| url=http://www.crimelibrary.com/blog/tag/clark-county/index.html| publisher=Crime Library| accessdate=May 11, 2014| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512220114/http://www.crimelibrary.com/blog/tag/clark-county/index.html| archivedate=May 12, 2014| df=mdy-all}} The woman had red hair and was between twenty-five and forty years old. She had been deceased for about six months.{{cite web| title=Clark Nevada Jane Doe January 2008| url=http://canyouidentifyme.org/ClarkNevadaJaneDoeJanuary2008| accessdate=May 11, 2014| year=2012}}{{cite web| title=Case File 277UFNV| url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/277ufnv.html| publisher=The Doe Network| accessdate=May 11, 2014}}{{cite web| title=Jane Doe: Case # 08-0675| url=http://canyouidentifyme.org/sites/default/files/ClarkNevadaJaneDoeJanuary2008.pdf| accessdate=May 11, 2014}}{{cite web| title=Nevada-Henderson, Clark County, Nevada| url=http://www.ncmissingpersons.org/missing-persons/unidentified-persons-2/nevada-henderson-clark-county-nevada/| accessdate=May 11, 2014}} ==New York== {{anchor|New York County Jane Doe (1998)}} ===New York County Jane Doe (1998)=== [[File:M98 06023 Namus Recon 002b.jpg|thumb|150px|New York County Jane Doe]] A woman was seen jumping into the path of an oncoming [[E (New York City Subway service)|E]] train at [[14th Street (IND Eighth Avenue Line)|14th Street]] station in New York, New York County, New York on November 9, 1998. She was white, approximately 105 pounds and at the height of five feet. She was estimated to be between twenty-three and thirty-three years old. Her hair and eyes were both brown in color. Her clothing consisted of a tan shirt, jeans, a handbag and a backpack. After she was struck by the train, she was taken to a local hospital where she was pronounced dead.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 6326|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/6326|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=December 29, 2014|date=November 10, 2009}} ==North Carolina== {{anchor|Lumberton Jane Doe}} ===Lumberton Jane Doe=== [[File:Lumberton Jane Doe Recon 001c.jpg|left|thumb|150px|Lumberton Jane Doe]] The body of a female between the ages of fifteen and twenty-two was found in Lumberton, North Carolina on June 2, 1978. She was located at the edge of a field and had died weeks before her body was discovered, resulting in decomposition that made determining her eye color impossible. The girl was between five feet one to five feet three inches tall and weighed 100 to 120 pounds at the time of her death. She was white with light brown hair and wore a short-sleeved shirt with a hood and several different colored stripes, jeans and white open toed shoes. She had several fillings and also had some of her molars removed. Her fingernails and toenails had been painted a reddish color. No signs of violence were observed on the body.{{cite web|title=Jane Doe 1978|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1184297/1#poster|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]]|accessdate=December 14, 2014}} {{anchor|Northampton County Jane Doe}} ===Northampton County Jane Doe=== {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [http://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1182692c1.jpg NCMEC reconstruction] | image2 = [http://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1182692x3.jpg Profile] }} On December 26, 1983, the partial skeletal remains of a young child were discovered by hunters in Northampton County, North Carolina, near Virginia. Due to animals and decomposition, many of the bones, the victim's hair and her clothing could not be recovered.{{cite web|title=Case Report - NamUs UP # 2196|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/full_report/2196|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=August 14, 2014}} The victim was a female, of African heritage, who was likely between four and six years old and may have been biracial. Although there was no apparent cause of death, she did have evidence of trauma to her face that occurred earlier in her life, possibly from abuse. Other details of the victim's life included that she could have suffered from ear infections and had damage to her nose prior to her death.{{cite web|title=Case File 717UFNC|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/717ufnc.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=August 14, 2014}} The girl had received dental care, as some fillings were found in her teeth. She may have been deceased for as much as a year before she was found.{{cite web|title=Jane Doe 1983|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1182692/1#poster|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]]|accessdate=August 14, 2014}} ==Ohio== {{anchor|Cuyahoga County John Doe}} ===Cuyahoga County John Doe=== [[File:484umoh Reconstruction 002b.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Cuyahoga County John Doe]] A man was pronounced dead approximately four minutes after he fell from a cliff in Euclid, Cuyahoga County, Ohio on May 8, 1981.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 7980|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/7980|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 13, 2015|date=October 7, 2010}} The exact cause of his death was determined to have been trauma to the chest. The man had been seen alive by a trio of men that stated he had claimed to have traveled to the states of New York, New Jersey, Ohio and California, the latter state he had planned to travel to as soon as he could come upon the means to fund his transportation. They also stated he had used cocaine and alcohol and bore the first name "Joe." His hair and eyes were brown and he was five feet seven inches tall and weighed 146 pounds. His clothing consisted of a jacket, a sweatshirt, a wool sweater, a T-shirt, a hat, a belt, two pairs of socks and a pair of brown boots. His age was believed to be between twenty and thirty and he carried various personal items, including cologne and suntan oil.{{cite web|title=Case File 484UMOH|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/484umoh.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=July 13, 2015}} {{anchor|Butler County Jane Doe}} ===Butler County Jane Doe=== {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [https://www.namus.gov/api/CaseSets/NamUs/UnidentifiedPersons/Cases/13635/Images/20924/Original Digital reconstruction] | image2 = [https://www.namus.gov/api/CaseSets/NamUs/UnidentifiedPersons/Cases/13635/Images/20921/Original Shirt] }} The remains of a white woman between 35 and 60 were discovered in a wooded area near [[West Chester, Ohio]] on March 7, 2015. The body was skeletonized, making the process of determining weight and eye color impossible. The woman was about 5'6" tall, had graying brown hair and unique and costly dental implants. She also had given birth in the past. She wore a white shirt with red and blue stripes and [[Faded Glory]] jeans. Some items were found nearby, including pairs of glasses and a denim bag, but may not have belonged to her.{{cite web |title=NamUs #UP13635 |url=https://www.namus.gov/UnidentifiedPersons/Case#/13635 |website=www.namus.gov |accessdate=20 October 2018 |language=en |date=12 March 2015}} The [[DNA Doe Project]] is currently processing her DNA to enter into a genealogy database in hopes to identify potential relatives to the decedent.{{cite web |title=Butler County Jane Doe, Cincinnati OH - DNA Doe Project Cases |url=http://dnadoeproject.org/case/butler-county-doe/ |website=DNA Doe Project Cases |accessdate=20 October 2018}} ==Oregon== ===Oak Grove Jane Doe=== {{main|Oak Grove Jane Doe}} Between April 12 and October 13, 1946, the dismembered remains of a middle-aged female were found floating in the [[Willamette River]] in [[Oak Grove, Oregon|Oak Grove]], south of [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]].{{cite news|work=Albany Democrat-Herald|location=Albany, Oregon|title=Woman's Head Believed That of Missing Lady|p=2|date=October 14, 1946|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25201690/albany_democratherald/|via=Newspapers.com}} {{open access}} Portions of the body were weighed down with curtain weights and bound with telephone wire.{{cite news|newspaper=The Daily Mail|location=[[Hagerstown, Maryland]]|p=14|date=April 13, 1946|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25201611/the_daily_mail/|via=Newspapers.com|title=Nude Torso Of Woman Is Found Hauled From Oregon River; Head, Arms And Legs Missing}} {{open access}} After the victim's head was recovered, it was found that she had no teeth and wore [[dentures]].{{cite web|work=[[KOIN]]|url=http://www.koin.com/news/unsolved-the-case-of-the-1946-willamette-river-torso_20171130084735662/870067267|title=Unsolved: The Case of the 1946 Willamette River torso|date=February 28, 2017|publisher=[[CBS]]|location=Portland, Oregon|archive-date=March 23, 2018|archive-url=http://archive.is/dHBcy|author=Gianola, Jeff}} ==="Annie Doe"=== {{anchor|Annie Doe}} {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [https://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1261134c1.jpg NCMEC reconstruction] | image2 = [https://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1261134x1.jpg Ring] | image3 = [https://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1261134x2.jpg Coat] }} On August 19, 1971, the skeleton of a female aged 14 to 25 was discovered in [[Cave Junction, Oregon]]. She was white with reddish-colored hair, which was frosted blond. She was between 5'2" and 5'9" at around 125 pounds. She had slightly protruding upper front teeth and had some fillings in her teeth. Some debris was noted to partially conceal the remains, which were found near the border with California. A hunting knife with deer blood was near the bones.{{cite web |title=404UFOR |url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/404ufor.html |website=www.doenetwork.org |publisher=[[The Doe Network]] |accessdate=10 October 2018 |date=16 December 2004}} The decedent wore a checked pink and beige coat, a turtleneck shirt, 34B bra, blue and white underwear, [[Wrangler (jeans)|Wrangler]] jeans and brown heeled shoes. She had several pieces of jewelry, one being a ring with the letters "AL" scratched into the mother of pear stone. She also carried 38 cents, the oldest dated 1970.{{cite web |title=NamUs UP# 10929 |url=https://www.namus.gov/UnidentifiedPersons/Case#/10929 |website=www.namus.gov |publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]] |accessdate=10 October 2018 |language=en}} She was reported as wearing a New Zealand-made bra, and DNA links were established with New Zealand by the DNA-Doe-project.{{cite web|url= https://www.stuff.co.nz/world/americas/108482871/mystery-us-skeleton-has-kiwi-dna-matches-was-wearing-new-zealandmade-bra |title= Mystery US skeleton has Kiwi DNA matches, and was wearing a New Zealand-made bra |publisher= Stuff (Fairfax) New Zealand |date= 3 May 2018}} Additionally, a map of northern California campgrounds was found in one of her pockets.{{cite web |title=Jane Doe 1971 |url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1261134 |website=missingkids.com |publisher=[[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]] |accessdate=10 October 2018}} ==Pennsylvania== {{anchor|Philadelphia County John Doe (1994)}} ===Philadelphia County John Doe (1994)=== [[File:Polaroid 94 2003 002a Reconstruction.jpg|thumb|150px|1994 Philadelphia County John Doe]] A sixteen to thirty year old Asian man was found dead minutes after his death in a train station on July 22, 1994 in Philadelphia, Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head. The gun, found at the scene, was traced to a Wisconsin resident who stated the weapon was stolen nearly a decade before. A note was left at the scene, presumably written by the young man, which stated: "With blood on his fingers and blood on his toes, he will have music wherever he goes. Don't fuck with the dragons." He had unique scars on various places on his head and neck as well as one on the back of his right knee and a birthmark on his chest. He wore a large shirt, white shoes, jeans, and white socks and underwear.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 7438|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/7438|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=December 29, 2014|date=July 22, 2010}} His teeth were in good condition, showing little sign of dental care. He was five feet nine inches tall and weighed 168 pounds.{{cite web|title=Unknown|url=https://identifyus.org/en/medias/full/6312|website=identifyus.org|publisher=Philadelphia Medical Examiner|accessdate=January 1, 2015|date=April 22, 1994}} {{anchor|Bushkill Jane Doe}} ===Bushkill Jane Doe=== [[File:250UFPA UP12414 Reconstruction 001.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Bushkill Jane Doe]] {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [https://identifyus.org/en/medias/full/23518 Shirt] }} The body of a female between thirty-five and fifty-five years old was found in brush on the shoulder of route 33 in [[Bushkill Township, Northampton County, Pennsylvania]] on October 23, 1987. She was of Caucasian descent and had blue eyes and blond hair. The height was estimated to be between five feet and five feet two inches tall and her weight was between 155 and 165 pounds. The decedent wore a red shirt with a decal of a woman's face, a multicolored bracelet, jeans and thermal long underwear with a snowflake design.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 12414|url=https://identifyus.org/en/cases/12414|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=March 30, 2015|date=May 1, 2014}} The woman is believed to have died due to a heart attack, yet her face suffered multiple lacerations from an undisclosed cause. She had died within 24 hours of being discovered.{{cite web|title=Case File 250UFPA|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/250ufpa.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=March 30, 2015}} ===Beaver County Jane Doe (2014)=== On December 12, 2014, a boy discovered the [[embalmed]] head of an elderly woman while walking in a wooded area of [[Economy, Pennsylvania]], approximately 15 miles northwest of [[Pittsburgh]]. Red rubber balls were in the eye sockets and no other body parts have been found. Police initially believed the head may have been taken from a funeral home, but now believe it may be linked to the illicit body parts trade.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/12/15/the-strange-sad-quest-to-match-a-severed-embalmed-head-with-its-body/}} ==Tennessee== {{anchor|Knox County Jane Doe (1987)}} ===Knox County Jane Doe (1987)=== {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [https://web.archive.org/web/20160304042150/http://canyouidentifyme.org/sites/default/files/Knox%20Tennessee%20Jane%20Doe%20June%201987.jpg Retouched morgue photograph] }} On June 1, 1987, the body of a young woman between twenty and thirty years old was found in [[Knoxville, Tennessee|Knoxville]], [[Knox County, Tennessee]]. The woman had brown hair and stood five feet five inches tall, weighing 100 to 120 pounds. A shotgun wound to the head was determined to be the cause of death, as she, along with the men who picked her up at a party, attempted a robbery, resulting in the woman being shot by the resident. She had apparently attempted to enter the house by breaking down the front door and then attempted to break through the screen behind it and was then killed.{{cite news| last=Balloch| first=Jim| title='Jane Doe' from 1987 is still a mystery| url=http://www.knoxnews.com/news/2009/nov/29/jane-doe-is-still-a-mystery/| accessdate=May 5, 2014| newspaper=Knoxville News Sentinel| date=November 29, 2009}}{{cite web| title=Case File: 607UFT| url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/607uftn.html| publisher=The Doe Network| accessdate=May 5, 2014}} Other clues to identification include a tattoo of the letters "BH" on her arm as well as a silver bracelet. She also had a past pelvic surgery and a metal plate as well as a metal pin in her leg, possibly the result of a car accident. Other healed injuries include fractures and damage to her vertebrae. A scar was found on her abdomen, presumably from a [[cesarean section]] or a [[hysterectomy]]. By studying the teeth, examiners believe she was from either the southeastern United States or the [[New England]] area. An autopsy revealed her blood alcohol was 0.13% at the time of her death.{{cite web| title=Knox Tennessee Jane Doe June 1987| url=http://canyouidentifyme.org/Knox%20Tennessee%20Jane%20Doe%20June%201987| accessdate=May 5, 2014}}{{cite news| last=Dobbs| first=Amy| title=Knox County Sheriff's office needs your help solving a cold case| url=http://www.myfoxmemphis.com/story/22497939/knox-county-sheriffs-office-needs-your-help-solving-a-cold-case#axzz30qPrRIrY| accessdate=May 5, 2014| newspaper=Fox News| date=June 4, 2013| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505173834/http://www.myfoxmemphis.com/story/22497939/knox-county-sheriffs-office-needs-your-help-solving-a-cold-case#axzz30qPrRIrY| archive-date=May 5, 2014| dead-url=yes| df=mdy-all}}{{cite news| title=Knox County "Jane Doe" could be from the Ark-La-Tex| url=http://www.kmsstv.com/news/knox-county-jane-doe-could-be-ark-la-tex| accessdate=May 5, 2014| newspaper=Fox News}}{{cite web| title=Autopsy Report on Jane Doe| url=http://content.foxtvmedia.com/whbq/JaneDoe.pdf| publisher=Knox County Sherriff Department| accessdate=May 5, 2014}}{{cite web| last=Evans| first=J.H.| title=Autopsy Report on Jane Doe| url=http://web.knoxnews.com/pdf/2009/112909autopsyweb01.pdf| accessdate=May 5, 2014| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141119061542/http://web.knoxnews.com/pdf/2009/112909autopsyweb01.pdf| archive-date=November 19, 2014| dead-url=yes| df=mdy-all}} ==Texas== {{anchor|Harris County Jane Doe (1976)}} ===Harris County Jane Doe (1976)=== [[File:Namus 4565 Reconstruction 3.jpg|150px|thumb|left|1976 Harris County Jane Doe]] A black female was found alive on the side of interstate 10 on September 30, 1976 in Houston, Harris County, Texas. She was taken to a hospital where she later died due to an undisclosed cause. The woman was {{convert|5|ft|8|in|m|spell=in}} tall and weighed {{convert|135|lb|kg}} and had black hair and brown eyes. She was clothed, wearing a green turtleneck sweater, a flannel shirt that was blue, a matching pair of jeans, pink underwear and brown shoes. Her ears were pierced, yet she wore only one earring. A ring with a turquoise stone accompanied with a second ring were among her jewelry. She was between twenty-five and thirty-five years old at the time of her death.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 4565|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/4565|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 12, 2015|date=October 13, 2008}} The woman had seen a dentist before her death, as fillings were observed in her mouth.{{cite web|title=Case file 734UFTX|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/734uftx.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=The Doe Network|accessdate=July 12, 2015}} {{anchor|Harris County John Doe (1979)}} ===Harris County John Doe (1979)=== {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [http://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1184344c1.jpg NCMEC reconstruction] }} A young Hispanic man was found deceased near a highway on April 28, 1979 in Houston, Texas. He had died a short time before, but was not recognizable because of suffering severe wounds from an unknown nature. He was between fifteen and twenty years old and was between five feet four to five feet eight inches tall at a weight between 135 and 145 pounds. His hair was dark and he had a mustache. He wore an orange shirt, black pants and boots. He had scars on his hip and arm, from a burn and vaccination, respectively. A scar on his knee was also located.{{cite web|title=John Doe 1979|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1184344/1#poster|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]]|accessdate=December 14, 2014}} {{anchor|Jersey Village John Doe}} ===Jersey Village John Doe=== [[File:UP 733 (Harris County) U0711043 Reconstruction 001a.jpg|thumb|150px|Jersey Village John Doe]] A man's body was found on November 15, 1982 in [[Jersey Village, Texas|Jersey Village]], [[Harris County, Texas]]. He was between thirty and forty at the time of his death when he was hit by a vehicle and subsequently succumbed to his injuries. He had six-inch brown hair, blue eyes and was five feet three inches tall at a weight of 116 pounds. He had received medical care when he was alive, as stitches were found under his right eye. The man also had scars on his chest, legs and hip. his clothing consisted of a green jacket, a shirt decorated with green and black squares, an undershirt, jeans, mismatched socks, brown gloves and cowboy boots.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 733|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/733|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=December 29, 2014|date=November 27, 2007}} ===Harris County Jane Doe (1983)=== [[File:92UFTX Reconstruction 005.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Harris County Jane Doe (1983) may have had the first name "Mary."]] A Hispanic or possibly Asian female was struck and killed by a moving vehicle on 7500 Katy Freeway on March 1, 1983 in Houston, Harris County, Texas. She was between the ages of twenty-two and twenty-eight at the time of death.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 4590|url=https://identifyus.org/en/cases/4590|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 12, 2015}} The woman was between five feet six and five feet seven inches tall and weighed 126 pounds. Her hair was black and her eyes were brown and she had crude tattoos on her body, of a cross and the letters "Z" or "N," "C" and "P" accompanied with some dots. She wore a green shirt with matching socks, blue jeans, a pink bra and white shoes. In a tan purse she carried, a plaid shirt, several papers and a comb were found. It is possible that her first name was "Mary."{{cite web|title=Case File 92UFTX|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/92uftx.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=July 12, 2015}} {{anchor|Rebel Ray}} ==="Rebel Ray"=== {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [https://www.dps.texas.gov/mpch_images/final/U8811001a.jpg Sketch] | image2 = [https://www.dps.texas.gov/mpch_images/final/U8811001b.jpg Profile] }} The skeletal remains of a male between the ages of 27 and 38 were found on October 3, 1988 in Georgetown, Williamson County, Texas. He died between a month and a year before due to an unknown cause. He was white with possible Native American or Hispanic ancestry. His hair was dark brown with some gray visible. He had a healed injury to his nose and he was likely of muscular build, with a height between 5'2" and 5'5". Although there was no clothing on the body, a pair of underwear and a hat were nearby. He was given the nickname "Rebel Ray" after the wording on the hat.{{cite web |title=55UMTX |url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/55umtx.html |website=www.doenetwork.org |publisher=[[The Doe Network]] |accessdate=25 October 2018 |language=en}}{{cite web |title=NamUs #UP4062 |url=https://www.namus.gov/UnidentifiedPersons/Case#/4062 |website=www.namus.gov |publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]] |accessdate=25 October 2018 |language=en |date=15 October 2008}}{{cite web |title=Case U8811001 |url=https://www.dps.texas.gov/mpch/Unidentified/unDetails/U8811001 |publisher=Texas Department of Public Safety |accessdate=25 October 2018 |date=10 October 2001}} {{anchor|Princess Blue}} ==="Princess Blue"=== {{distinguish|Princess Doe}} {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [http://www.txdps.state.tx.us/mpch_images/final/u0310014a.jpg Sketch] | image2 = [http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/images/137UFTX2.jpg Class ring] | image3 = [http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/images/137UFTX5_LARGE.jpg Side of class ring] | image4 = [http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/images/137UFTX.jpg Horse emblem] | image5 = [http://doenetwork.org/cases/images/137UFTX1.jpg Another ring] }} On September 10, 1990, a skeleton of a female between fifteen and twenty-five of slight to medium build was discovered in [[Manvel, Texas|Manvel]], [[Brazoria County, Texas]], between one and five years after the death occurred, underneath a tire and a pile of brush. Six rings and a pearl bracelet were found on the body, including a 1975 blue class ring that originated from [[Lee High School (Houston)|Robert E. Lee High School]]. Another was a gold ring containing several clear stones. The class ring, which was upsized twice to a size 9, is not believed to have originally belonged to her, as it pre-dated the period when she would have graduated from high school. She was likely white, but likely had someone of African descent in her ancestry. Originally, she was believed to be Hispanic, but this has been since ruled out.{{cite web|last=Warder|first=Robin|title=10 Mysterious Cases Involving Unidentified People|url=http://listverse.com/2013/06/14/10-mysterious-cases-involving-unidentified-people/|accessdate=April 8, 2014|date=June 14, 2013}}{{cite news| last=Masilo| first=Craig| title=Woman found dead 17 years ago in Manvel remains unidentified| url=http://www.houstonpress.com/2007-09-13/news/cold-case/| accessdate=May 5, 2014| newspaper=Houston Press| date=September 12, 2007}} She had a defect visible behind one of her knees, possibly from a tumor. Although Princess Blue's cause of death has not officially been determined, two of her ribs were fractured. Toxicology tests on the bones indicated no evidence of drug use. Dental records of the female are on file, which include details that she had multiple cavities that had not been attended to before her death.{{cite web|title=Case File 137UFTX|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/137uftx.html|website=doenetork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=July 9, 2015}} Princess Blue's DNA has also been processed for future comparison with missing persons.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 989|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/989|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 9, 2015|date=April 16, 2008}} {{anchor|Gregg County Jane Doe}} ===Gregg County Jane Doe=== {{for|the homicide victim found in 2006|Lavender Doe}} {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [http://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1225447c1.jpg NCMEC reconstruction] | image2 = [http://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1225447x1.jpg Profile] }} The nearly completely skeletonized remains of a young adult female were found on May 21, 2002 by construction workers in Gregg County, Texas.{{cite news|last1=Stephens|first1=Marshall|title=Sheriff seeking public's help to identify remains found in East Texas|url=http://www.kltv.com/story/25407508/sheriff-seeking-publics-help-to-identify-remains-found-in-east-texas|accessdate=December 25, 2014|work=KLTV|publisher=ABC|date=May 1, 2014}} She was between seventeen and twenty-eight when she died, approximately two years before her remains were found on Highway 135. She was white, five feet one to five feet four inches tall and had a petite build.{{cite web|year=2014|title=Jane Doe 2002|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1225447/1#poster|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]]|accessdate=December 25, 2014}} She had a cleft palate that was never treated, which would be obvious to those around her. The cause of her death is unknown and her eye color and hair color were not possible to determine due to the decomposition of the remains. It has not been reported if any clothing was recovered from the scene.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 3299|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/3299|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=December 25, 2014|date=October 15, 2008}} Her face was reconstructed in 2014 by the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children.{{cite news|last1=Weso|first1=Micheal|title=Gregg Co. seeking identity in human remains cold case using 3D technology|url=http://www.ketknbc.com/news/crimewatch/gregg-co-seeking-information-on-human-remains-cold|accessdate=December 25, 2014|work=KETK|publisher=NBC|date=May 1, 2014}} ==="Smurfette"=== {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [http://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1205209c1.jpg NCMEC reconstruction] | image2 = [http://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1205209x1.jpg The T-shirt which Jane Doe was found wearing] }} On October 16, 2012, an anonymous tip led police to find an unidentified female body inside a black trash bag in Houston, Texas near Walters Road.{{cite web|last1=Stanton|first1=Robert|last2=Lezon|first2=Dale|title=Skeletal remains found in a trash bag on north side|url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Body-found-in-trash-bag-in-N-Harris-County-3953158.php|website=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=July 22, 2017|date=October 16, 2012}} She is estimated to be fifteen to seventeen years old, 4-foot 7 to 5-foot 3 tall, possibly of mixed Caucasian and African American descent, and presumed to have died during the month of September 2012. She had a pronounced overbite and dental fillings in three of her lower molars.{{cite web|year=2017|title=Jane Doe 2012|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1205209|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing and Exploited Children]]|accessdate=July 22, 2017}} She became known as "Smurfette Doe" as she was found wearing a distinctive blue-green T-shirt with [[Smurfette]] depicted one the front with daisies and the text "He smurfs me, he smurfs me not." She was also wearing a size 5 tan cargo pants as well as a black bra (34C), pink thong underwear, and a bobby pin in hair.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 10722|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/10722|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 22, 2017|date=October 29, 2012}}{{cite web|title=Case File 1312UFTX|url=http://www.doenetwork.org/cases/1312uftx.html|website=doenetork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=July 22, 2017|date=May 20, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Fernandez|first1=Demond|title=Investigators work to identify teenage girl found dumped in garbage bag in northwest Harris County|url=http://abc13.com/archive/8912478/|website=ABC13 Houston|accessdate=July 22, 2017|date=December 7, 2012|language=en}} ==Virginia== ==="Female Stranger"=== {{main|Female Stranger}} A young woman who died mysteriously in 1816. She is buried in Alexandria, Virginia and her grave remains a tourist attraction since her death."The Female Stranger" Kansas City Times (Kansas City, MO) Sunday, September 11, 1887. {{anchor|Alleghany County Jane Doe (1985)}} ===Alleghany County Jane Doe=== The skeletonized remains of a female were discovered by a hunter on November 18, 1985 in Alleghany County, Virginia. Only the skull, which was found first, and torso of the subject were recovered. The hair color, eye color, height and weight could not be determined. She was, however, estimated to be a white female between the ages of twenty and forty-nine years old. She had died approximately four months before, as examination indicated. No clothing was found at the scene and it was not possible to recover her fingerprints, as the advanced state of decomposition prevented it. Although her dental information has never been recorded, her DNA was successfully extracted and developed into a suitable profile. She has yet to be forensically reconstructed.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 6796|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/6796|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 28, 2015|date=March 23, 2010}} {{anchor|Caroline County John Does}} ===Caroline County John Does=== {{Double image|right|Caroline County John Doe (older).jpg|150|Ruther Glen, VA John Doe.jpg|150|Reconstructions of the older and younger Caroline County John Does, respectively.}} The skeletonized remains of two Hispanic males, deceased for about two months to one year, were discovered in Ruther Glen, Caroline County, Virginia on November 10, 1988. The pair were related paternally, although it is unknown how closely. The older subject was estimated to be around the age of thirty-five and forty-five and was at a height between five feet four and five feet six inches and weighed between 130 and 140 pounds. He was found with two shirts, two hats, brown pants, two distinct belt buckles, cowboy boots, a green sock, and a red pair of underwear. One of the belt buckles suggested he was from a different country, as the word "Mexico" was written on it.{{cite web|title=Case File: 2439UMVA|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/2439umva.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=July 20, 2015|date=October 26, 2014}} The man's clothing appeared to have been recently purchased.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 6507|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/6507|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 20, 2015|date=December 23, 2009}} The younger male was between seventeen and twenty-five and was about five feet three to five feet seven inches tall; his weight was approximately 135 pounds. He wore a blue and gray shirt and blue jeans.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 6301|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/6301|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 20, 2015|date=December 3, 2009}} Like his companion, he wore cowboy boots.{{cite web|title=Case File: 1348UMVA|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/1348umva.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=July 20, 2015|date=December 8, 2009}} Four molars were missing from his mouth, and may have been extracted while he was alive at some time.{{cite web|title=John Doe 1988|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1184371/1/screen|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]]|accessdate=July 20, 2015}} {{anchor|Stafford County John Doe}} ===Stafford County John Doe=== [[File:Stafford JD Angles.jpg|thumb|left|Reconstruction of the Stafford County John Doe]] On September 28, 1990, the skull of a male, lacking a mandible, was found in a field belonging to a farm in Stafford County, Virginia. The decedent was estimated to be a white male between fifteen and eighteen years old at the time of his death, which had occurred one to three years before. Little was available for a coroner to examine, yet a distinct-shaped tooth was noticed as well as some fillings.{{cite web|title=John Doe 1990|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1184375/1/screen|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]]|accessdate=July 7, 2015}} As the lower jaw from the skull was never located, those that reconstructed the John Doe consequently had to estimate how it may have appeared. No other remains of the subject were ever found, which prevented any estimation of his height and weight. Investigation into discovering the male's identity has been extensive, as 186 missing persons have been excluded from the case, including [[David Stack]], who was identified as a different unidentified subject in 2015.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 2229|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/2229|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 7, 2015|date=July 19, 2008}} {{anchor|Newport News Jane Doe}} ===Newport News Jane Doe=== [[File:Newport News Jane Doe angles.jpg|thumb|Newport News Jane Doe]] The mummified remains of a woman were discovered on June 6, 2014 in Newport News, Virginia after maintenance workers found her body concealed underneath a sheet. The female was between the ages of twenty-five and forty-five years old and was of an indeterminable race. Her body was in such poor condition that her height and weight were not possible to determine, as were the color of her hair and eyes. One or both of the woman's hands were not found with the body, but there were, at least, the presence of fingers with the remains that were successfully printed and recorded. She wore a shirt of an unknown color and a pair of "athletic pants" that were dark in color and had three stripes visible. Extensive investigation has been put forth in this case, as the DNA of the woman has been processed and her dental records were also recorded, ruling out nearly 2,500 missing people, such as [[Tammy Lynn Leppert]] and [[Disappearance of Morgan Nick|Morgan Nick]].{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 12683|url=https://identifyus.org/en/cases/12683|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=28 July 2015|date=30 June 2014}} ==Washington== ===Mill Creek Shed Man=== {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [https://www.namus.gov/api/CaseSets/NamUs/UnidentifiedPersons/Cases/13502/Images/18133/Original Reconstruction by Natalie Murry] | image2 = [https://www.namus.gov/api/CaseSets/NamUs/UnidentifiedPersons/Cases/13502/Images/18129/Original Shirt] }} A black man's remains were discovered in a shed in [[Mill Creek, Washington]] on January 11, 2015. His cause of death remains undetermined and there wasn't any indication he was murdered. He was between 50 and 65 at the time of his death and was between 5'9" and 6'1." His weight estimation could not be ascertained. The man's right little finger had been amputated at one point during his life. He was found clothed, wearing a plaid tan-colored button-down [[Eddie Bauer]] shirt, a short sleeve turtleneck shirt, tan [[Banana Republic]] pants and black wool socks. He also carried a red lighter. The area where the remains were discovered was a known place for transients to reside. It is rumored a man known as Jerry Diggs or Deggs lived near the location the body was found, although there is no evidence they were the same person.{{cite web |title=NamUs #UP13502 |url=https://www.namus.gov/UnidentifiedPersons/Case#/13502 |website=www.namus.gov |accessdate=20 October 2018 |language=en |date=6 February 2015}} The man's DNA was submitted to the [[DNA Doe Project]], an organization that uses forensic genealogy to find potential identities for unidentified remains. The results are currently being processed.{{cite web |title=Mill Creek Shed Man - DNA Doe Project Cases |url=http://dnadoeproject.org/case/mill-creek-shed-man/ |website=DNA Doe Project Cases |accessdate=20 October 2018}} ==Wisconsin== {{anchor|Delafield John Doe}} ===Delafield John Doe=== [[File:Delafield John Doe Reconstruction 002.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Delafield John Doe]] A young man in Delafield, Waukesha County, Wisconsin was killed after colliding with a tree while driving a stolen vehicle on September 14, 1977. He was a white male between seventeen and twenty-five, had brown hair, hazel eyes and weighed 155 pounds at the height of six feet tall. When he died, he wore a white sports jacket over a long sleeved shirt with various colors. He also wore a watch, distinctive patterned pants with gray and white squares along with black shoes and socks. He also had a cigarette lighter engraved with "To John Love Lauri," indicating that "John" may have been his first name or he had stolen it from someone bearing the name. A business card from an Illinois store known as "Johnny's Mobile Home Sales" was also found at the scene.{{cite web|title=John Doe 1977|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMU/1184612/1#poster|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]]|accessdate=December 12, 2014}} {{anchor|Milwaukee County Jane Doe}} ===Milwaukee County Jane Doe=== {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [http://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1232237c1.jpg NCMEC reconstruction] | image2 = [http://api.missingkids.org/photographs/NCMU1232237x1.jpg Profile] }} The body of a female of African heritage was found floating near a dock in Milwaukee, Wisconsin on March 16, 1982. She may have been deceased for several months, but had been well preserved due to the low temperatures in the river. The girl is believed to have died at the age of fifteen to twenty-five, possibly as old as thirty-five. She was five feet four inches tall and weighed 137 pounds. Her hair was styled in an Afro and was black with reddish tints. Her face was reconstructed by the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children in 2014 after her mortuary photographs were submitted. This was done due to her face being swollen from being in the water for a period of time. She had dental fillings and two root canals in her life and also had a scar leading from her abdomen to her pubic region. The victim's death is considered accidental, as there were no signs of foul play on her body.{{cite news|last1=Luthern|first1=Ashley|title=Investigators trying to solve mystery of woman found in 1982|url=http://www.jsonline.com/news/investigators-trying-to-solve-mystery-of-woman-found-in-1982-b99396464z1-284101131.html?ipad=y|accessdate=December 13, 2014|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|agency=Journal Sentinel|date=November 27, 2014}} She wore a brown coat, bluish-green socks, boots, tan hat, brown top and a sweater.{{cite news|title=Man finds woman's body in river|url=http://county.milwaukee.gov/ImageLibrary/Groups/cntyMedicalExaminer/PSMDS017.jpg?Large|accessdate=December 13, 2014|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|agency=Journal Sentinel|date=March 17, 1982}} {{Anchor|Rock County John Doe}} ===Rock County John Clinton Doe=== {{main|Rock County John Doe}} [[File:Clinton WI John Doe.jpg|thumb|left|FBI rendering of what John Clinton Doe may have looked like at age 20 (2014).]] {{external media | align = | width = | image1 = [http://findjcd.org/images/sketches/JCD-16YearsOld_PhojoeStamp3.jpg Colorized sketch of JCD (2016)] | image2 = [http://findjcd.org/images/sketches/RiverGuy.jpg Police artist sketch of River Guy (1994)] }} The remains of a young man, mostly skeletonized, were discovered on November 26, 1995 in Bradford Township near Clinton, Rock County, Wisconsin. He is locally known as "John Clinton Doe" or "JCD".{{cite web|work=[[ViCap]]|publisher=[[FBI]]|title=ViCAP ALERT UNIDENTIFIED PERSON – JANESVILLE, WI|url=https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/vicap/unidentified-persons/john-clinton-doe/vicap-alert-john-clinton-doe-clean.pdf|accessdate=February 26, 2016}}{{cite news|title=Image of what John Clinton Doe may have looked like released|url=http://www.channel3000.com/news/Image-of-what-20-year-old-cold-case-John-Doe-may-have-looked-like-released/38028138|accessdate=February 26, 2016|work=Channel 3000|agency=CNN|publisher=Morgan Murphy Media|date=February 16, 2016|location=Madison, Wisconsin}} The individual's body was positioned on its stomach in sleeping pose in a remote area on the bank of Turtle Creek. There was not enough evidence to determine the official cause and manner of death, but it is likely he fell asleep or passed out and succumbed to hypothermia. The body is believed by some to be that of a lightly bearded man, known as "River Guy", who was seen on October 16, 1994, appearing intoxicated, running in the same creek near where the body was found a year later.{{cite web|title=Case File 1207UMWI|url=http://doenetwork.org/cases/1207umwi.html|website=doenetwork.org|publisher=[[The Doe Network]]|accessdate=July 6, 2015|date=December 11, 2014}} The subject seen in 1994 wore clothing similar to the small-medium clothes found with the body, which included camouflage pants, a black shirt, and a multicolored jacket. Black Nike athletic shoes and underwear with a [[Bart Simpson]] decor were also found. The male's personal items included a lighter, a homemade pendant and a black wrist watch. Physical examination of the body by forensic anthropologists indicated that the decedent was white, between seventeen and twenty years old, had long brown hair, was between five feet five to five feet seven inches tall, and likely weighed around 140 pounds. He had died approximately one year prior, reinforcing the theory that the body belonged to River Guy.{{cite web|title=NamUs UP # 4757|url=https://identifyus.org/cases/4757|website=identifyus.org|publisher=[[National Missing and Unidentified Persons System]]|accessdate=July 6, 2015|date=January 22, 2009}} Forensic testing was eventually performed on the bones. A DNA profile was sent to the FBI's National CODIS system. Stable Isotope Analysis indicated he had spent a significant amount of time in the Great Lakes region of the country, specifically Wisconsin, Michigan and Minnesota.{{cite web|title=John Doe 1995|url=http://www.missingkids.org/poster/NCMC/1234507/1#poster|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]]|accessdate=July 6, 2015}} 197 missing persons have been ruled out as identities of JCD.{{cite web|title=Unidentified Remains Known As: John Clinton Doe|url=http://www.findjcd.org/reports/RuledOut_Chart.php|website=findjcd.org|publisher=New Look Investigations|accessdate=April 11, 2018|date=April 11, 2018}} Even so, the search for JCD and River Guy continues, with hopes the name of this victim and his family can someday be found and his remains returned to them for proper burial and remembrance. In the mean time, John Clinton Doe is buried in Johnstown Center Cemetery, Rock County, Wisconsin. His skull was cremated. {{clear}} == See also == *[[List of unidentified murder victims in the United States]] ==References== {{reflist|3}} ==External links== {{commons category|unidentified decedents}} *[http://www.doenetwork.org/ The Doe Network] *[https://identifyus.org/en National Missing and Unidentified Persons System] *[http://www.missingkids.org/home National Center for Missing and Exploited Children] {{Unidentified decedent}} [[Category:Unidentified decedents in the United States| ]] [[Category:Unsolved deaths|unidentified decedents in the United States]] [[Category:Death in the United States-related lists|unidentified decedents in the United States]]

{{Orphan|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Mao Zhu-Quan |native_name = 茅祖权 |birth_date = 1883 |birth_place = [[Haimen]], [[Jiangsu]], [[Qing dynasty|Qing China]] |death_date = 1950 |death_place = [[Shanghai]], People's Republic of China |party = [[Kuomintang]] |occupation =Secretary-General of the Republic of China, Justice Minister of the Republic of China, R.O.C.Presidential National Policy Consultant, Head of the Jiangsu Civil Administration }} '''Mao Zuquan''' ({{zh|t=茅祖權}}; 1883–1952) <ref>《二十世纪中国人物传记资料索引·下篇4》作生于1883年，卒于1952年</ref>was a [[Kuomintang]] politician of the [[Republic of China (1912–49)]].<ref>二十世纪中国人物传记资料索引 下篇 4，上海辞书出版社，2010年</ref><ref name=yu>余克礼、朱显龙，中国国民党全书（下），陕西人民出版社，2001年</ref><ref name=nr>[http://www.nrnet.cn/imrnet/literature/PersonageInfoDetails.aspx?pid=MR000000000000000374 茅祖权，NR百科，于2015-02-02查阅]</ref>
==Early life and career== Born in [[Jiangsu]] and of Haimen ancestry in 1883, Mao Zuquan studied in [[Japan]] as a student during his younger days before being appointed as a member of the Nationalist Party of China's Kuomintang National Assembly in 1912. The National Assembly ({{zh|t=國民大會|p=Guómín Dàhuì}}) refers to several [[parliament]]ary bodies that existed in the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]] at this time. He quickly rose through the ranks and became a prominent individual in the Chinese government and society and in 1924, he was chosen by China's Kuomintang Central Committee as a candidate for the position of the executive committee member. In his later years, he served a number of positions in the Nationalist government. He was appointed as the head of the Jiangsu Civil Administration on [[Mainland China]] under the rule of the government of the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]]. He also served as [[Nationalist Government (China)|Nationalist China]] Secretary of the Official Punishment Committee as well as the Secretary-General to the President of the Republic of China. He also served as the Presidential National Policy Consultant and as Nationalist Republic of China's first Minister of the [[Ministry of Justice (Republic of China)]].<ref name=nr/><ref name=yu/>
==Legacy== The [[Chinese Civil War]] (1927–49) forced the Nationalists to retreat to the island of [[Taiwan]] after the victory of the Chinese Communists in Mainland China. Mao Zhuquan stayed behind on the mainland, rather than relocate with [[Chiang Kai-shek]] and his troops to the island with the rest of his family. In 1950, he was arrested by the [[Communist Party of China]] while in [[Shanghai]] and subsequently imprisoned for refusing to cooperate with the Communists. In 1952, he died in prison as a result of a [[hunger strike]] in opposition to the Communists.<ref name=nr/><ref name=yu/>
His descendants now reside in [[China]], [[Taiwan]], as well as the United States in [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles County]], [[California]] and [[Houston]], [[Texas]]. ==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mao, Zuquan}} [[Category:1883 births]] [[Category:1952 deaths]] [[Category:Republic of China politicians from Jiangsu]] [[Category:Deaths by starvation]] [[Category:Politicians from Nantong]] [[Category:People from Haimen]]

page.title: Mercury: The Afterlife and Times of a Rock God

revision.text:
{{Infobox play | image = Mercury_Play_Front_Cover.jpg | image_size = 286 × 450 pixels | caption = Front cover of the first published edition of the play | name = Mercury: The Afterlife and Times of a Rock God | writer = [[Charles Messina]] | premiere = November 24, 1997 | place = Sanford Meisner Theatre New York, NY | characters = Freddie Mercury | setting = A room | orig_lang = English | subject = | genre = [[Monodrama]] }}
'''''Mercury: The Afterlife and Times of a Rock God''''' is a [[monodrama]] written by [[Charles Messina]] about the life and death of [[Queen (band)|Queen]] lead singer [[Freddie Mercury]]. It presents Mercury in the moments just after his death, during which he is confronted with self-examination as he "seeks redemption before a God unimpressed by his celebrity."<ref>{{cite book|last=Messina|first=Charles|title=Mercury: The Afterlife and Times of a Rock God|year=2009|publisher=Original Works Publishing|location=United States|isbn=978-1-934962-52-7|pages=back cover}}</ref>
== Synopsis ==
Farrokh Bulsara was a boy of Persian heritage who never quite fit into his skin or his teeth. It wasn’t until he became a young man that he discovered his talent and true nature, and was reborn as Freddie Mercury. After a brilliant career, with the arenas empty and the lights out, on the night of November 24, 1991, Freddie is forced to surrender his celebrity and face the frailty of his own humanity. As he succumbs to AIDS, the worldwide icon seeks redemption before a God unimpressed with celebrity. In his ultimate struggle to make sense of his grim fate, Mercury realizes that his fame, fortune, and talents are no longer enough to sustain him; that beyond the darkness of his fears, shines a light far brighter than the star he was on Earth.<ref>http://www.originalworksonline.com/store/monologues/mercury-the-afterlife-and-times-of-a-rock-god/{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== Premiere ==
{{Infobox play|left| | name = | image = Mercury_Afterlife_Goncalves_1998.jpeg | image_size = 190 × 265 pixels | image_alt = Mercury Second Run Postcard Gonçalves | caption = Promotional postcard for the second run of ''Mercury: The Afterlife and Times of a Rock God'' }}
The play debuted at the [[Sanford Meisner]] Theatre in [[New York City|New York City's]] [[Chelsea, Manhattan|Chelsea]] district on November 24, 1997 at 6:48pm - the 6th anniversary of Mercury's death.<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC On This Day: 24 November 1991: Giant of rock dies|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/november/24/newsid_2546000/2546945.stm|publisher=BBC News | date=November 24, 1991}}</ref> The part of Freddie was played by [[Khalid Gonçalves]] (né Paul Gonçalves).<ref name="Lefkowitz">{{cite web|last=Lefkowitz |first=David |title=Freddie Mercury To Rise Again, Off-B'way, Nov. 24 |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/35833-Freddie-Mercury-To-Rise-Again-Off-Bway-Nov-24 |publisher=Playbill.com |date=November 24, 1997 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021131502/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/35833-Freddie-Mercury-To-Rise-Again-Off-Bway-Nov-24 |archivedate=October 21, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
On opening night of the play, then-[[New York City Council]] member [[Tom Duane]] introduced the show.<ref name="Lefkowitz"/>
The play ran every night until December 7.
== Second run ==
The play began its second run on February 14, 1998.
On February 17, rock musician [[Billy Squier]], a longtime friend of Freddie's, debuted a song that he wrote in memory of him titled ''I Have Watched You Fly'' on stage before a performance of the play. He introduced the song by saying, "I knew Freddie as a friend. I'm honored to share the stage with him in the afterlife."<ref>{{cite news|last=Barron|first=James|title=PUBLIC LIVES; Theater Records|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9806E2DC153FF93BA25751C0A96E958260|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 18, 1998|author2=Martin, Douglas}}</ref>
The play was also performed every night during the second run, ending on March 8, 1998.
Proceeds from the ticket sales of both runs were donated to [[Gay Men's Health Crisis]] and [[Mercury Phoenix Trust|The Mercury Phoenix Trust]].<ref name="Lefkowitz"/>
== Revival & tour ==
{{Infobox play | name = | image = Mercury_Afterlife_Darvish_2004.jpg | image_size = 190 × 265 pixels | image_alt = Mercury Third Run Postcard Darvish | caption = Promotional postcard for the third run of ''Mercury: The Afterlife and Times of a Rock God'' }}
On January 11, 2004, the play experienced a successful revival with a three-month run at the [[Triad Theater]], also in New York City, with Messina again as writer/director and featuring [[Amir Darvish]] in the role of Freddie.<ref>{{cite web|last=Simonson|authorlink1=Robert Simonson |first=Robert |title=Bohemian Rhapsody: Freddy Mercury Play Begins Performances Off Broadway, Jan. 11 |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/83716-Bohemian-Rhapsody-Freddy-Mercury-Play-Begins-Performances-Off-Broadway-Jan-11 |publisher=Playbill.com |date=January 11, 2004 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021131929/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/83716-Bohemian-Rhapsody-Freddy-Mercury-Play-Begins-Performances-Off-Broadway-Jan-11 |archivedate=October 21, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
In 2006, the play also had a special, limited engagement from August 30 to September 2 at The Art House in [[Provincetown, Massachusetts]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Mercury: The Afterlife and Times of a Rock God in Provincetown Art House August 30|url=http://provincetownjournal.com/events/entry/mercury-the-afterlife-and-times-of-a-rock-god-in-provincetown-art-house-aug/|publisher=ProvincetownJournal.com|date=May 21, 2006}}</ref>
== Publication ==
In 2009, the play was published by Original Works Publishing. Proceeds from the sale of the play will be donated to [[AmfAR|AmfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Messina|first=Charles|title=Mercury: The Afterlife and Times of a Rock God|year=2009|publisher=Original Works Publishing|location=United States|isbn=978-1-934962-52-7|page=1}}</ref>
== Reviews ==
Both incarnations of the play have received favorable reviews from Queen fans and from the music and theater press, notably [[Billboard Magazine|Billboard]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Marone|first=Mark|title=On Stage|url=http://www.billboard.com/search/?keyword=Goncalves&x=0&y=0#/archive/read?id=3gkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=frontcover&query=1997&date=1997-12-13|newspaper=Billboard|date=December 13, 1997|page=46}}</ref> [[The New Yorker]],<ref>{{cite magazine|magazine=The New Yorker|date=January 26, 2004|page=11}}</ref> [[Time Out New York]], [[Zagat Survey]],<ref>{{cite book|title=Zagat Survey New York City Theater Guide Spring Edition|year=2004|publisher=Zagat Survey|isbn=978-1-57006-587-3}}</ref> and ''[[Backstage (magazine)|Backstage]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Forbes|first=Harry|title=Mercury: The Afterlife and Times of a Rock God|magazine=[[Backstage (magazine)|Backstage]]|date=November 28, 2003|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/services/amusement-recreation-services/4569275-1.html}}</ref>
On November 26, 2011, the play was recognized by Flavorwire.com in their list of ''15 Artistic Tributes to Freddie Mercury.''<ref>{{cite web|last=Temple|first=Emily|title=The Show Must Go On: 15 Artistic Tributes to Freddie Mercury|url=http://flavorwire.com/235246/the-show-must-go-on-15-artistic-tributes-to-freddie-mercury/5|publisher=FlavorWire.com|date=November 26, 2011}}</ref>
== Controversy ==
There was no Queen or Freddie Mercury music in the play.
In a 1997 interview with [[Playbill.com]], Gonçalves said, "All the things I've seen about Mercury focus on the music, career and persona; very little has been discussed about the person. Not only did Charles write a play about Mercury, he captured the humanity."
